malvarozo (bot.) rose-mallow, hollyhock (Althaea rosea).
malvavisko (bot.) marshmallow (Althaea officinalis).
malyoto bathing-tights, -dress; (tights as for acrobats, cf. kalzego).
mamo breast (of woman); udder (of animal); mamoza full-breasted; mamala mammary; mamatra mammilary; mampinto nipple, teat, dug (of animals).
mamifero mammal; (class) mammalia.
mamilo* (anat.) mammilla: nipple (cf. mampinto).
mamuto mammoth.
mani (antiq.) manes, ancestral spirits, shades.
manao manna.
mancho (long) handle, hilt, haft; neck (of musical instr.); mancho di balayilo broom-stick; guvernilo rudder, helm.
mandareno mandarin.
mandarino mandarin orange; tangerine orange.
mandato money order (as P.O.; cf. cheko).
mandelo almond; mandeliero a. tree (Prunus Amygdalus); mandellakto milk of a.; mandelatra okuli a. eyed; mandelsiropo a. syrup, orgeat (cf. orjato).
mandibulo mandible; (zool.) either the upper or lower, part of the beak of a bird; (anat.) lower jaw; (cf. maxilo); mandibulala mandibular.
mandolino (mus.) mandolin.
mandoro (mus.) mandore: a kind of stringed lute.
mandragoro (bot.) mandragora; European mandrake (Atropa mandragora).
mandrelo (tech.) mandril, mandrel. Def.: Utensilo por kurvigar plaki, dilatar tubi, e.c.; IV-336.
mandrino (tech.) drill-chuck.
manejo manege: riding-school; -academy.
manekino manikin, lay figure, dummy. Def.: Figuro imitanta la formo di homo o di animalo; ofte artikizita; III-327.
maneto (tech.) hand-lever, movable handle or knob.
mango (fruit) mango; mangiero mango tree (Mangifera).
mangano (min.) manganese.
manglo (fruit) mangrove; mangliero mangrove tree (Rhizophora Mangle).
mangusto (zool.) mongoose (Herpestes).

manio mania, monomania: derangement of the mind especially upon a single subject; manieto hobby, fancy; maniika, manioza; maniiko, maniozo maniac(al); (cf. monomaniiko). Ex.: Il havas mani(et)o skribar, kompozar. Mani(et)o pri kultivado di tulipi.

maniero manner, way of doing anything; or acting; method; mannerism; (pl.) behavio(u)r, deportment, (cf. kustumo, modo); omna laboristo laboras segun sua maniero every workman has his own way of doing a thing; parol (od, maniermodo) mode, manner of speech; il havas tre agreabla manieri he has very pleasing manners.
manifestar (tr.) to manifest, make to appear, make known; manifesta manifest, no longer concealed (cf. evidenta, videbla, notora, publika). Ex.: Deo manifestas su per sua laboruri. Manifesta eroro.
manioko (bot.) manioc, manihot, cassava (genus: Manihot).
maniplo (Rom. antiq., eccl.) maniple.
manipular (tr.) to manipulate; to treat, work or operate with the hand.
manipulatoro sounding-key; apparatus used to send messages (telegraphic, etc.) by breaks in the current.
manivelo crooked handle, crank; manivele plear ario to grind out a tune (as on a hand organ); manivelarboro crank-shaft; maniveldrilo breast-drill.

manjar (tr.) to eat: chew and swallow; (fig.) to eat away; consume; manjaretarto nibble, to eat little; manjaro, manjarado a meal, eating; manjarajo something eaten or to be eaten; food, victuals (cf. nutriva, disho); manjarilaro eating utensils; manjaregero glutton; manjarotrogo manger, crib, eating tough; manjareyo, manjarochambro eating place, dining chamber, refectory; manjarosako nosebag (for horses).
manometro manometer: a pressure or vacuum gauge; steam gauge.
manoto handcuff; manotizar, manotligar to handcuff.
manovrar (tr., intr.) to maneuver (manœuvre) (troops, ships); (fig.) to manage, or bring about, with skill (an affair, etc.).
mansardo garret; story or room under a sloping roof (cf. atiko).
mantear (tr.) to toss (ulu) in a blanket.
mantelo (garment) mantle, cloak; (arch.) mantel (as over a fire-place); manteleto short cloak; (R.C. ch.) mantelletta; mantelsako portmanteau; clothes-bag; (cf. valizo).

mantenar to keep fast, hold fast, sustain (in a state of stability); mantenar karpenturo per fero to uphold timberwork with iron; to maintain, preserve: keep in the same state; mantenar ordino, familio to maintain order, a family; la manteno di la legi the maintaining of the laws. Def.: Tenar en la sama pozeso o stando; VI-51.
mantilio mantilla.
mantiso* the decimal part of a logarithm.

manuohand; manuala manual; manulaboro hand (or, manual) labo(u)r; manulibro hand-book, manual:manuskribita hand-written (cf. manuskripto); manuagar (tr.) to handle, wield; (fig.) to manage; manuagebla which can be handled, workable; (fig.) manageable; manufabrikar (tr.) to make (ulo) by hand; (cf. fabrikar); manuedo handful; manuedope by handfuls; manufrapo blow, cuff, thump; manudorso back of hand; manupreso hand-pressure; handshake; manuveturo hand-truck, barrow; manuvishilo hand-towel; manuapogilo hand-rest; manusako hand-bag, reticule.
manuskripto manuscript.
manzanilo (bot.) manchineel (-tree) (Hippomane mancinella.).
mapo map; reliefa mapo relief map.

maro sea (cf. oceano); mara, marala of or relating to the sea, marine, maritime (cf. navala); maristo seaman, sailor; maro meza (od,plena) main sea, high sea; marportuo sea-port; marala nauzeo sea-sickness; markolo, stretajo arm of the sea, strait; marfisharo sea-fish; maroaglo (orni.) white-tailed sea-eagle (Haliaetus albicilla); marhundo (mam.) seal (Phoca); marospumo sea-foam; (fig.) meerschaum; marospuma pipo meerschaum pipe.
marabuto* Marabout. Def.: Mohamedista kleriko od ermito; VII-280.
maraskino* maraschino: a kind of liquor.
marasmo (med.) marasmus: progressive emaciation.

marchar (intr.) to walk, step, tread; (of soldiers) to march; march(ad)o walk(ing), march(ing); marchar grandapaze to stride; marcho acelerata forced-, quick-, hurried-march or walk; marchomodo, marchmaniero way of walking, gait (cf. pazo); marchanto, marchero pedestrian, walker, marcher; marchario march-music, -tune; marchetar to trip along (of children). Def.: Facar pazi, pozar alterne la pedi sur la sulo, irge qua esas la direciono o la skopo di ta ago (ne rezervata a la militala marcho, o la militala komandi); IV-464.
marchandar (tr.) to bargain for, beat down the price of, haggle about; marchand(ad)o bargaining; il longatempe marchandis ta domo he was a long time bargaining for that house.
marcipano marzipan, marchpane: a kind of sweetmeat.
mardio Tuesday.
mareo tide, ebb and flow (cf. fluxo, refluxo); mareego bore, eagre: rush of water up an estuary; wave caused by meeting of two tides.
mareografo* marigraph: tide-gauge register.
mareometro* tide-gauge.
margarino (chem.) margarin; (com.) oleomargarine, artificial butter.
margravo (title) margrave.
margrito (bot.) marguerite, oxe-eye daisy (Chrysanthemum leucanthemum); margriteto English daisy (Bellis perennis).
mariabalno (chem.) water-bath; (cook.) double-boiler.

mariajar (tr.) to marry; legally unite in wedlock (by an official, priest, minister); (cf. spozigar, aliancar); la komonestro mariajis li the mayor married them; mariajar su to get married (kun ulu); mariajo, mariajeso marriage, matrimony, wedlock; mariajo legala civil marriage; mariajanto, mariajero person officiating at a marriage, match-maker; mariajebla marriageable; mariajatulo married man, (nova) bridegroom; mariajfesto wedding, nuptials; mariajfestanti, mariajgasti wedding-party, -guests; mariajanunco banns. V. exp.: L’ago mariajar implikas 3 personi; la homulo e la homino mariajata, e la legal (o religial) oficisto, qua mariajas (unionas) li. Do, segun rigoro, la verbo mariajar povas havar quale subjekto nur l’oficisto. Per extenso, on povas dicar ke la homulo e la homino mariajas su, pro ke lia volo esas ya la kauzo di la mariajo; II-726. La sacerdoto mariajas Maria e me. La patrulo di Maria grantis Maria e me kom spozino. Maria spozuligis me. Me spozinigis Maria, od, me mariajis me kun Maria.
marioneto (also fig.) marionette, puppet; filo marioneto dancing jack.
marjino margin (of book, of paper); (fig.) border, edge (of anything); notizar en marjino to note or write in the margin.
«mark» (money) mark; (weight) mark; an old weight: 8 oz. (ounces).

marko mark: token by which anything is known; stamp; markizar to mark; markifar to produce a mark, leave a trace; markosigno distinctive mark or sign; (cf. indiko, signo, atesto); marko sur mutono, sur bokotuko mark on a sheep, on a napkin; doganala marko stamp of the Customs.
markez(ul)o marquis, markezino marchioness.
markotar (tr., hort.) to layer: bend a shoot or branch to the ground and cover with earth so as to take root; markotajo branch or shoot thus layered.
marmelado marmelade.
marmito pot (for boiling); porridge-pot.
marmoro marble; marmora of marble (statuo, e.c.); marmorala, marmoratra relating to marble; marble-like, marmoreal; marmorumar to stain or vein like marble.
marmoto (zool.) marmot (Arctomys Marmota); (U.S.) woodchuck, groundhog.
marno marl.
marodar (intr.) to maraud: rove in quest of plunder; (tr.) to plunder.
marokina, marokino morocco (leather).
marono (fruit) marron: horse-chestnut (Aesculus Hippocastanum); maronea, maronbruna chestnut-colo(u)red; (cf. kastano).
marquizo marquee: a large field tent; an ornamental verander or penthouse overhanging a balcony, window or door.
Marso (myth., astron.) Mars.
marsho, marshlando marsh, morass, bog, fen, swamp.
marshalo marshal, field-marshal.
marsuino porpoise (Phocaena communis).
marsupialo (zool.) marsupial.
marto (month of) March.
martelo hammer; martelagar to hammer (cf. malear); martelag(ad)o hammering; martelagebla malleable; ligno martelo mallet, pestle, beetle; (cf. malio); vapor martelego steam-, forge-hammer.
Martinpeskaro (orni.) kingfisher (Alceda hispida); (cf. alcedo).
Martinsomero St. Martin’s summer: warm, damp season in England and southern Europe from November to about Christmas.
martiro, martirulo, martirino (also fig.) martyr; martirigar martyrize (ulu).
martro (zool.) marten (Mustela Martes).
marvelo wonder, marvel, prodigy. Def.: Ulo qua efikas astoneso od admiro per aparta beleso, grandeso o stranjeso, mem per superhomeso o supernatureso; II-19.
maso mass: body of matter cohering in one body, usually of considerable size; (cf. amaso, bloko, turbo).
masajar (tr.) to massage (ulu).
masakro (tr.) to massacre. Def.: Mortigar un (od, plu generale) plura personi kruele o senbezone; III-698.
masho mesh, link (as in knitting, etc.); mashkuraso, mashkuto, mashtuniko coat of mail.

mashino machine, engine; mashini, mashinaro engines, machinery; mashinisto machinist: one who runs or constructs m.s; mashinala mechanical; relating to machinery (cf. makanikala); mashinagar to use or operate a m.; mashinizar to furnish m.s to; mashinifar to produce, make m.s; exploz mashino infernal machine; milit mashino engine of war; sut mashino sewing m.; vapor mashino steam-engine; mashinskribar (tr.) to write with a m., to typewrite (ulo); (cf. skrib mashino, mashinisto, mashinero typist).
mashinacar (tr.) to machinate: plan or contrive in secret with evil purpose.
masiva massive, bulky; masivo a large solid mass (as of masonry); a block (of flowers, trees, etc.); bulk (of a mountain or hill).
maskar (tr.) to mask (to cover the face with a mask, not travestiar); maskilo a mask; maskita, maskito masked (person); maskofesto, maskitaro masquerade; maskiteso (fig.) a disguise.
maskarono (arch.) carved or moulded face (or figure). V exp.: To ne esas masko, ma vizajo plu o min groteska, skultita IV-336.
maskula, maskulala, maskulatra male, masculine; maskulo a male; maskula genro gender; maskuleso masculinity.
masonar (tr.) to do mason’s work on: to build (with stone, brick, etc.); to wall up, seal up (a door, etc.); masonisto mason, bricklayer.
masto mast; masteto small m., spar, pole; ye mimasto at half-mast; masti, mastaro masts (of a ship, etc.); mastizar to put m.s on, in (a ship, etc.); mastizilo sheer legs.
mastico mastic: a resin from the mastic tree; any of the pasty cements, esp. putty; masticizar to putty.
mastikar (tr.) to chew, masticate; mastikajo something to chew; cud; mastikendo (med.) masticatory; mastikachar to munch.
mastodonto mastodon.
mastro master:person having authority; mastrino mistress; mastreso mastery; su mastreso self-mastery, self-control; sub mastro foreman, overseer.
mato mat, matting (of straw or other materials).
matadoro matador.
matematiko mathematics.

materio (also fig. as of discourse, book, etc.) material, matter (out of which something is made); materiajo material object, substance; materiala material: relating to matter; materioza substantial, not formal; materiatra material (analogous to); materialisto, materiista materialist(ic); materialismo materialism; materialeso materiality; materio prima, kruda raw material; materiigar to materialize: to make (a spirit) visible in or as a material form; materialigar to invest with material characteristics, to substantialize.
matida dull, hollow (of sound); mat(t), dead, dull, not shiny, glossy (of colo(u)rs, etc.). Ant.: sonora, brilanta.
matino morning, forenoon: time from dawn to midday; matinala m., f.; matutinal; ca matine on (or in) this m., f.; morga matino tomorrow m., f.; (esas) frumatine (it was) early in the m.
matloto* matelot: a kind of fish-stew; a kind of sailor’s dance, hornpipe.

matro mother; matrala maternal; matreto little mother; (fig.) mamma; matreso maternity: motherliness; matrala linguo mother-tongue; matraquo (chem.) mother-liquor. V. exp.: Matro esas la sentimental equivalanto di patrino; VI-535.
matraco mattress.
matraso (chem. instr.) matrass.
matrico (tech.) matrix.
matrikulo matricula: register in which names are entered consecutively, as for a hospital, prison, society, etc.; matrikuleskar, matrikulizar to matricula.
matrono matron.

matura (also fig.) ripe, mature: having become completely developed; maturigar to cause to ripen or come to maturity; matura frukti ripe fruits; matura evo mature age; matura abceso ripe (suppurating) abcess; matura delibero mature deliberation.
matutino (R.C. Ch.) matins. Def.: «Ofico» di la matino; V-340.
mauzoleo mausoleum.
maxilo maxilla: upper jaw bone (cf. mandibulo); maxilala maxillary.

maxim(e) (adv. of comparison) most; maxim(e)a highest; maxim(e)o maximum; maxim(e)multo the generality, majority, the most; maxim(e)multe posible the most possible; maxim(e)granda posibla the greatest possible; maxim(e)bona the best; maxim(e)a sorgo the greatest care; lu laboris maxime he works most; la maxim granda asno ek la tri the biggest ass of the three; maxim(e)alta highest; maxim(e)a valoro highest value; (fig.) highest price; maxim(e)ala relating to the maximum; maxim(e)klara posible as clear as possible, the clearest possible. Ant.: minim.
mayo (month)May.
mayoliko majolica.
mayonezo (cook.) maayonnaise (-sauce).
mayoro (milit. title) major.
mayuskulo capital or uncial letter, majuscule. Ant.: miniskulo.

mazo mace. Def.: Baston(ego) plu grosa ye un extremajo kam ye l’altra; ica servas kom mancho, e l’enesma havas nodi, o klovi o saliaji; II-709. La mazo moderna esas uzata quale ceremoniala insigno, ex.: en parlamento.
mazurko mazurka (dance and music).
meceno Maecenas; (fig.) patron of art and science.
mecho wick (of lamp, of candle); tinder; (artil.) quick-match; mechofusilo match-lock.
medalio medal.
medaliono medallion; (fig.) locket.

medio (also nat. sciences) environment, surroundings; (of people) circle, set; (cf. cirkumaji); en la intelektala, etikala e sociala medio in the intellectual, moral and social environment; media ambient, surrounding.

mediacar (tr.) to mediate: to intervene, interpose between people or in something to harmonize or reconcile; mediaco mediation, intervention; mediacanto, mediacero mediator; intermediate; agent; middleman, go-between; mediacanta intermediate; (cf. mediata).
mediana*, mediano (geom., and fig. in zool., anat., bot.) median (middle), mesial. Def.: Rekto qua juntas somito di triangulo a la mezo dil latero opozita; VII-280.

mediata mediate: intermediate, not direct or immediate, indirect; mediatigar to mediatize: to make intermediate, render mediate; mediate intermediately, indirect; ne mediata immediate: without intervention of another object, cause or agency; (cf. quik); mediatajo something intermediate, intermediary (object; cf. mediacanto).

medicino (art, profession) medicine; (cf. medikamento); medicinala medical; medicinisto, medicinulo, medicinino one who occupies himself with medicine, even theoretically (cf. mediko); medicindoktoro doctor of m., medicinstudent(ul)o student of m.

mediko, medikulo, medikino physician, doctor; medikala medical; medikacho quack. V. exp.: Per mediko on devas komprenar medicinisto praktikanta, kontre ke medicinisto (segun l’etimologio) esas irgu qua okupas su profesione pri medicino (mem nur teoriale). Profesoro di medicino, exemple, esas medicinisto, ma povas ne esar mediko. Kuracisto signifikas ta qua (profesione) kuracas, sive mediko, sive ne; VI-141.
medikamento medicine, medicament; medikamenta, medikamentala, medikamentatra medicinal; medikamentizar to apply, give medicine to (ulu).
meditar (tr., intr.) to meditate, think over, ponder (cf. projetar); Ex.: Meditar (pri) ula verajo, la paroli di evangelio-libri. Il pasas sua tempo en meditado. Meno meditema.
mediumo (spiritistic) medium.
medulo medulla: (bone) marrow; (of plants) pith.
meduzo (zool.) medusa: jelly-fish, sea-nettle; Meduzo (myth.) Medusa.
Mefistofelala, Mefistofelatra Mephistophelean.
mefito mephitis: noxious or foul exhalation, especially from earth; (mines) choke-damp.
megafono megaphone: (large) speaking trumpet.
megalita megalithic: consisting of large stone; megalito megalith (monument).
megasporo* (bot.) megaspore.
megasporangio* (bot.) megasporangium.
megaterio* (paleon.) megathere.
megero shrew, vixen, termagent.

mejisar (tr.) to taw (skins). Def.: Specala maniero preparar la peli, precipue la mikra peli: mikra bovyuno, mutono, mutonyuno, kapro-yuno, por fabrikar ganti, delikata shui, e.c. La mejisado esas specala karakterizata per to ke la tanago di la peli, vice facesar per tanoza extrakturi, quale la tanago propre dicita, esas facata per specala mixuro blankatra kompozita de aluno, vitelo e marala salo; VI-245.

mekaniko (science of) mechanics; mekanikala mechanical; relative to mechanics or the laws of motion (cf. mashinala); mekanikisto mechanician: one learned in the theories of mechanics (cf. mashin(if)isto). Ex.: omna movi di korpi esas mekanikal, la libera falo di korpo, same kam la falo di vapor-martelo.

mekanismo (philos., mechan, and fig.) mechanism, machinery; structure; mechanical parts. Def.: Ensemblo di la mekanikal relati, kun egardo a la dispozeso di la parti; VII-205. Ex.: La mekanismo do horlojo od altra mashino. La mekanismo esas ulo abstraktita, la strukturo, la dispozeso di la parti di la aparato.
mekanisto (philos.) representative of mechanism.
mekanomorfoso* mechanomorphosis.
melankolio (of persons) melancholy; (med.) melancholia; melankolioza melancholy, dispirited, gloomy (of mind); (cf. trista). Ant.: gayeso.
melanismo* (biol.) melanism.
melaso molasses, treacle.
meleo* melee; a general had to hand fight.
melinito melinite (-powder).
meliso (bot.) balm, balm-mint (Melissa officinalis).
melkar (tr.) to milk (an animal).
melodio melody; melodia, melodiala, melodioza, melodiatra melodious, musical, sweet, tuneful.
melodramo melodrama.
melolonto maybeetle, cockchafer (Melolontha vulgaris).
melono melon, muskmelon (Cucumis Melo); aquo melono watermelon (Cucumis Citrulis); kantalupo melono cantaloup.
melopeo (mus.) melopoeia.

mem (adv.) even, still, (in comparson); (emphasis) really, indeed (cf. ya); mem se even if; mem plu bona still better, better yet; yes, me konfesas, ke mea manui esas mem tre sordida yes, I admit that my hands a really very dirty; ica pano esas bona, ma ita esas mem plu bona that bread is good but that is even better; il meritas estimo, mem amo he merits esteem, even love.
membro member (of society, community, party, parliament, of an equation); limb (of body); membro (di frazo) clause (cf. klauzo); membri, membraro members, limbs; membroza limbered, membered.
membrano (anat., bot.) membrane.
«memento» (R.C. ch.) memento: prayers for living and dead.

memorar (tr.) to remember, recollect, have a memory of; (cf. merkar); memorigar to cause (ulu) to remember, remind, bring to mind, commemorate; memor(ad)o (act, faculty) memory, remembrance; memorajo what is rembered, recollection; memorigilo reminder, souvenir, keepsake; memore by heart; memorinda memorable; memorigo commemoration, remembrance; memorigiva, memorala commemorative; memornoto note of reminder, memorandum; memorlibro memo. book; ri memoro reminiscence, recollection.
memorando memorandum; (of societies, academies); (dipl.) memorial: a note or informal state paper used in diplomacy.

menajo housekeeping: administration, cleaning and general management of a house, especially apart from mere cooking arrangements; menajisto, menajulo, menajino, menajestro housekeeper. Def.: Domal (hemala) ekonomio o servado; IV-66.
menajerio menagerie. Def.: Kolekturo de animali rara o sovaja por expozo; III-327.
mencionar (tr.) to mention, make mention of; honoroza, mencionizanta menciono honorable mention. V. exp.: vid. citar.
mendikar (tr.) to beg (for alms); mendikanto, mendikero, mendikisto beggar, mendicant.
menhiro* menhir: standing stone.
meningo, meningi (anat.) meninx, meninges.
meningito (med.) meningitis; meningito cerebrospinala cerebro-spinal m.
menisko* (opt., phys.) meniscus.
menso* (of abbeys) revenue; (fig.) table-money, allowance for table.
menstruar (intr., physiol.) to menstruate, have the monthly flow; menstruo menses.

mentomind: seat of consciousness, thought, volition and feeling; mentality: cast or habit of mind (cf. spirito, psiko, intelekto); mentala mental; mento militistala a military mind: an intelligence which looks at all matters from a soldier’s viewpoint; mento partisala a partisan mind or spirit; mento publika public spirit or mind; mentomediko physician of the mind, alienist. ?EFIS
mentiar (intr.) to lie, tell a falsehood (pri, per); mentietar to fib.
mentoro mentor (counselor).
menuomenu, bill of fare.
menueto minuet (dance or air).
menuzar (intr.) to do fine carpenter’s or joiner’s work; menuzisto cabinet-worker, joiner (cf. ebenisto). V. exp.: vid. karpentar.
mercenario (milit.) mercenery (soldier)
mercero (Eng.) mercer’s business, haberdasher’s trade. (U.S.) dry-goods business; merceristo mercer, haberdasher: a dealer in textile fabrics, trimmings, and small articles of dress.
meridiana lineo, meridiano meridian.
merino merino (-sheep); merinlano merino wool.
meringo (cook.) meringue: a kind of icing and cake made of it.
meristemo* (bot.) meristem.
merizo wild cherry; meriziero wild cherry tree (Prunus avium).

merkar (tr.) to mark, to impress (ulo) on one’s memory, to retain or remember) a thing, keep in mind, (cf. memorar); vorti facile merkebla words easy to keep in mind; merkez mea vorti mark my words; me merkos to I will bear that in mind; merkovorto catch-word, cue-word, key-word. V. exp.: Merkar expresas ideo simila a lernar, tamen min konsideranta la peno e l’intenco; III-495.
merkato (aslo fig. as in polit. econ.) market: public place for selling. Def.: Vendeyo publika; III-466. Stando di la ofro e demando di vari en un urbo o loko; II-76.
merkurdio Wednesday.
merkurio (chem.) mercury, quicksilver.
merlo (orni.) blackbird (Turdus merula).
merlano (ich.) whiting (Gadus Merlangus).
merlono* (fort.) merlon. Def.: Parto (solida) di muro inter du kreneli; VII-280.
merlucho (ich.) merluce: the European hake (Merlucius vulgaris).
merogonio* (embryol.) merogony.
meromorfa* (math.) meromorphic.
merotomio* merotomy: division into parts.
meso (R.C. Ch.) mass; meslibro missal, prayer-book; meso senkanta low mass
mesajo message: official communication, diplomatic, parliamentary; (cf. letro, sendajo).
mesio (also fig.) Messiah; mesiana, mesiala Messianic.

meskina mean, paltry (person, act); narrow, illiberal (ideas, policy); stingy, niggardly (persons, policy); shabby (room, person); meskinajo mean or paltry thing or act, shabby trick. Def.: Qua indijas larjeso, alteso (precipue etikala); III-10.
mestica, mestico (of persons, animals) half-breed, mixed-breed; mestizo: a peson of mixed Spanish and American Indian blood; (cf. mulato, hibrido); (cf. V-33).

mestiero trade, handicraft: occupation or business in which manual or mechanical labo(u)r is necessary, as that of a carpenter or mason; mestierala technical, craft; mestieristo artisan, mechanic; il esas mestiere tornisto he is a turner (or lathe-worker) by trade.
metabolio* (biol.) metabolism.
metacentro* (hydros. and shipbuilding) metacenter (metacentre)
metacinezo* (biol.) metakinesis.
metafazo* (biol.) metaphase.
metafiziko metaphysics.
metaforo (rhet.) metaphor.
metafrazo metaphrase: literal translation. Def.: Expliko qua konsistas en tradukar loko (frazo) en plura klara, simpla e vulgara vorti; V-485.
metageometrio* metageometry.
metakarpo (anat.) metacarpus.

metalo metal; metala, metalala, metaloza metallic: of m., relaing to m., full of m.; metalajo m. object; metalizar to metallize; to coat or impregnate with m.; metalifo metallurgy; ore production (cf. metalurgio); metalifisto metallurgist; metalfilo wire; metallaboristo m.worker; metalvazaro, metalajaro ironmongery, hardware.
metalografio metallography.
metaloido* (chem.) metalloid.? DEFS
metalurgio* metallurgy: science and art of preparing metals from the ores (not the extracting of ores; cf. metalifo).
metamero* (zool.) metamere.
metamorfosar (tr.) to metamorphose.
metano* (chem.) methane, marsh-gas.
metastabila (physical chem.) metastable.
metatarso (anat.) metatarsus.
metatezo (gram.) metathesis.
metempsikoso metempsychosis, transmigration of souls.
meteoro meteor.
meteorologio meteorology; meteorologiisto meteorologist.
metilo* (chem.) methyl.

metodo method: special or definite system of procedure; (of things) –ala methodical; (of persons) –oza methodical; metodale, metodoze methodically. Ex.: Il facas omno segun metodo (od, metodoze). Metodala aranjo.
metodismo (rel.) methodism: doctrine of methodists; metodisto methodist (member of a religious sect).
metodologio methodology.
metolo* (chem.) metol.
metonimio (rhet.) metonymy.
metonomazio metonomatosis. Def.: Chanjo di propra nomo per traduko, qua celas ol; V-485.
metopo (arch.) metope.

metro (metric) meter (metre): 1.093 yards; (poet.) meter; metroquadrato square meter: 1.196 square yards; metro kubo cubic meter: 35 cubic feet; metrala (measure or verse) metrical. Note: A list of metric abbreviations may be found in IV-608-9.
metriko (science of) versification, prosody, scansion.
metrologio* metrology.
metronomo metronome.
metropolo metropolis: a chief or capital city.
metropolito (eccl.) metropolitan (bishop).

meza, mezo middle, midst; meze di in the middle of; meza, mezala middle, medial, median; mezgrada, mezvalora (of quantities) average; (math.) mean; (gen.) middling, mediocre, tolerable (cf. pasabla); mezgrado, mezvaloro average, mean, mediocrity; mezvalore moderately, indifferently; mezepoko the Middle Ages; mezepokala medieval; mezeva of middle age; meza stando (od, situeso) moderate circumstances; meza fosto (di fenestro) mullion; mezosoprano mezzo-soprano; meza proporcionalo (geom.) mean proportional.
mezentero* (anat.) mesentery.
mezodermo* (embryol., zool.) mesoderm.
mezolabo* (instr.) mesolabe.
mezotinto* mezzotint(o).

mezurar (tr.) to measure (with an instrument), to survey (land); mezur(ad)o measure, measurement, measuring; (mus.) time, measure; bar; mezurilo an instrument for measuring; mezurebla measurable; sen mezura immeasurable, immoderate; excessive, exorbitant; super mezuro over-measure; agro mezuristo land (or, field) surveyor. V. exp.: vid. evaluar.
mi mi, third note of diatonic scale.
miasmo miasma: noxious exhalation.
miaular* (intr.) to mew: to cry as a cat, to caterwaul, miaou.
micirklo hemicycle, half-circle.
mideo demigod.
midekeduo half-dozen.

mielo honey; (fig.) sweetness; mielala, mieloza, mielatra honeyed, melliferous; mielifar to produce honey; mielaquo hydromel, mead; mielkuko gingerbread; mielmixuro oxymel: a mixture of vinegar and honey; mieltempo honeymoon.

mieno (of the face) look(s), mien, countenance, mienacho affected, lackadaisical, simpering look; mieno superba haughty look; facar mieni, mienachi to put on airs, mince, simper, smirk; ne judikez homo segun lua mieno do not judge a person by his looks.
mifacio (photog.) pose between face and profile; (cf. miprofilo).
mifarmajo metairie: land (or implements) leased for half-share of produce; miado metayage; miisto, miero metayer.
mifratulo half-brother.
migrar (intr.) to migrate; migranta, migrema migrating; (fig.) itinerant; migranta uceli migrating birds.
migreno megrim: a kind of sick or nervous pain affecting one side of the head, hemicrania. ?DeFIR
migrenino* (med.) a kind of remedy for megrim or hemicrania.
mikao (min.) mica.
mikorizo* (biol.) mycorrhiza.

mikra little, small; (cf. poka); mikreta, mikracha tiny, wee; mikrope little by little, bit by bit; mikrigar to make small, belittle; (cf. mingrandigar, diminutar), mikrokosmo microcosm. Ex.: Mikra spaco, chambro, homo, sumo, nombro, merito. Ant.: granda.
mikrobo microbe.
mikrofono microphone.
mikrografo* micrographer: one versed in micrography.
mikrografio micrography: description of microscopic objects.
mikrometro micrometer.
mikrono* micron: 1/1000 of a millimeter (millimetre).
mikropilo* (bot., zool.) micropyle.
mikroskopo microscope.
mikrosomo* (biol.) microsome.
mikrosporo* (bot.) microspore.
mikrosporangio* (bot.) microsporangium.
mikrozoo microzoa: animals of microscopic smallness.
mil thousand; milo a (one) thousand; milesma (ordinal) 1000th ; milimo (fraction) 1/1000 (part); milyara millenary; (cf. cent, du for derivatives).
milano (orni.) kite (Milvus ictinus).
milio mile: 5280 feet; 1609.35 meters (metres).
miliardo billion; 1000 millions; miliardiero billionaire.
milico militia; milicano militiaman.
miligramomilligram: 0.015 grain.
milimetro millimeter (millimetre): 0.039 inch.
miliono million; milioniero millionaire.

militar (intr.) to (make) war; (fig.) to militate; (por, kontre); militigar to cause to make war; militanto, militisto fighter, combatant, warrior; militala military: relating to war; militistala military: relating to warriors; militema combative, pugnacious, bellicose; militarto art of war; militruzo stratagem (of war); militistaro armed force of a country (cf. armeo); militjudicio court-martial; militala kaptito prisoner of war; militnavo warship; militnava naval.

militarismo militarism; militaristo militarist: a believer in militarism; militarigar to militarize: to bring into a condition of (or imbue with) militarism. Ex.: On dicas, ke la maxim bona metodo kuracar militaristo esas igar lu militisto.
milumo half-light, twilight, subdued light.
miluno half-moon.
milyeto (bot.) millet (Panicum miliaceum).
mimar (tr.) to mimic: express by dumb show, as for ridicule; mimanto, mimisto mimic, mime.
mimetika* (zool.) a mimicking (animal); mimetikeso mimicry; imitative resemblance of one animal to another or to some inanimate object.
mimondumo demi-monde.
mimoso (bot.) mimosa, sensitive plant (genus: Mimosa).

min(e) (adv.) less (Note: The short form: min is used when followed by adjective or verb; as, min granda smaller; the longer form: mine is used when not followed by word which it modifies, as at the end of a sentence; il laboris mine he worked less; min bela less beautiful; parolez min multe speak less; min multo the lesser; min kam ultempe less than ever; min multa pekunio less money; sempre min less and less. V. exp.: Min esas diminutala; minus esas sustracionala. Ex.: Esante min durstanta kam me, il drinkis un glaso minuse; II-738. Ant.: plu. Note: In distinction from E. usage where «less» is used adjectivally, min is always an adverb, therefore : min multa homi, notmin homi.
minar (tr.) to undermine, to mine: extract ores, etc.; (cf. subdestruktar) (milit.) to sap; mineyo a mine; mineyala pertaining to mines: la rivero minis la rivo the river undermined the bank.
minacar (tr.) to menace, to threaten (ulu, per ulo). Ex.: Il minacis mortigar me. La muro minacis krular (E. the wall totters). Kolero esas minaco.
minareto minaret.
mineralo mineral; mineraligar to mineralize: transform into a mineral; mineralizar to mineralize: to cover or impregnate with mineral.
mineralogio mineralogy; mineralogiisto mineralogist.
minestrelo minstrel: poet, singer of the Middle Ages.
mingrandigar to lessen, make smaller; (cf. mikrigar, mingrosigar, diminutar).
mingrosigar to reduce in size; (cf. tenuigar).
miniaturo miniature; a small and delicate painting, as a portrait; a representation on a much reduced scale.

minim(e), minim(e)a (superlative of min) least, lowest, minimum; minim(e)o minimum; minim(e)a nombro (necesa por valideso di voti) quorum; min bona, min kurajoza least good, least courageous; min multa bruiso posibla least possible noise: minim chera least dear, the cheapest; la minim alta monto the lowest mountain; skribar pri kozi quin on komprenas minime to write things about which one understands least; (cf. note on form in min(e).
miniona small and dainty, daintily pretty; minionino a daintily pretty girl or woman; (fig.) darling, pet; miniona boko a pretty (and small) mouth; miniona pedo a dainty foot.

ministerio administrative or executive department of a government of which a ministro is the head (cf. V-158); la ministraro demisionis, ma la ministerii ankore funcionis the ministers have resigned but the «ministries» (administrative departments) still carried on their work.

ministro (state functionary) minister; ministraro cabinet, ministry (collective); ministrala ministerial; ministreyo government office; dum la ministreso di Sro. X during the ministry of Mr. X; chef ministro premier, prime minister.
miniumo minium: red oxide of lead; (paint) red-lead.
minora (jur.) minor: under age; (logic, music, eccl.) minor; minoreso (of age) minority; minora modo minor key. Ant.: majora.
minoritato minority: the smaller number. Ant.: majoritato.
minotauro (myth.) Minotaur.
minto (bot.) mint (genus: Mentha); minto krispa curly mint (Mentha crispa); piprominto peppermint (Mentha piperita).
minucio minutia, trifle, minor detail: minucii minutiae; minuciema (person) particular; attentive to detail, fastidious, hairsplitter; minuciemacho fuss-budget, busybody.

minus (arith., alg.) minus; di plus tri minus un facas (od, esas) quar two plus three minus one makes four; il pagis a me un dollar minuse he paid me one dollar less (i.e. he took one dollar from the price); un glaso minuse one glass less. V. exp.: vid. min.
minuskulo (print.) small letter; (in manuscripts) miniscule. Ant.: mayuskulo.
minuto (of time: astron., geom. of degree) minute.

minvalorigar to depreciate: to lessen the value of; to undervalue, underrate; disparage; la abundo de pekunio minvalorigas la valoro the abundance of money depreciates its value; komercaji minvaloreskas goods are beginning to depreciate; minvalorigar persono to depreciate a person.
mioceno (geol.) miocene.
miologio* myology.
miombro half-shade, partial shadow; (astron.) penumbra; (cf. milumo).
miopa, miop(ul)o near-sighted, myopic (person); miopeso myopia.
miozoto (bot.) myosotis: forget-me-not (genus: Myosotis).
miprofilo (photog.) half-profile (taken from the back; cf. mifacio).
miro myrrh.
mirabelo «mirabelle»: a small yellow plum (European).
mirajo mirage; (fig.) delusion.
miraklo miracle; mirakla miraculous: truly supernatural; miraklala miraculous: relating to miracles; miraklatra miraculous: mervelous,wonderful; miraklifanta wonder-working, working miracles.
miriado myriad: an immense number; (antiq.) ten thousand.
miriametro myriameter: ten thousand meters (metres); 6.2 miles.
miriapodo (zool.) myriapod; milliped. (class. Myriapoda).
mirmekofago (zool.) ant-eater, ant-bear (Myrmecophaga).
mirmekofila* (zool.) myrmecophilous.
mirmekoleono (ent.) ant-lion (genus: Myrmecoleon).
mirto (bot.) myrtle (genus: Myrtus).
mirtelo (fruit) bilberry; mirteliero bilberry plant: European whortleberry plant (Vacinium Myrtillus).
misaliancar (su) to contract a misalliance; to marry beneath one; o misalliance, a bad match.
misaplikar (tr.) to misapply (ulo, ad, sur).
misdeskriptar (tr.) to misrepresent, wrongfully describe (cf. misprezentar).
mis(dis)donar (tr.) to misdeal (cards).
misduktar (tr.) to mislead (ulu).
miseventar (intr.) to come to any harm, to happen unluckily, to turn out ill; miso mischance, mishap, misadventure.
misfero hemisphere.
misformacar (tr.) to misform, misshape; miso, misuro malformation.
misinterpretar (tr.) to misinterpret.
misionar (religious, scientific, etc.) mission; misionisto, misionero missionary.
misirar (intr.) to go astray, lose one’s way.
misjudicio (jur.) erroneous judgement.
misjudikar (tr.) to misjudge (not legal).
miskalkular (tr., math.) to miscalculate.
miskomprenar (tr.) to misunderstand, misapprehend.
miskonceptar (tr.) to misconceive.
miskonocar (tr.) to misunderstand (something perceptible to the senses), to mistake; (cf. konocar).
miskontar (tr.) to miscount.
misnomar, misizar to misname, give a wrong name to (cf. nomar).
mispafar (intr.) to miss fire.
mispelo (fruit) medlar; mispeliero medlar tree (Mespilus).
mispozar (tr.) to put in the wrong place. V. exp.: vid. egarar.
misprezentar (tr.) to present wrongly, misrepresent. Ex.: Il misprezentis (od, mis-deskriptis) la stando di la afero, la fakti di la kazo.
mispronuncar (tr.) to mispronounce.
misrezono wrong reasoning, a fallacy.
«Miss» (title) miss.
misselektar (tr.) to mischoose.
missendar (tr.) to missend (ulo); to misdirect (a letter, etc.).
mistaxar (tr.) to mistax, wrongfully assess.
mistelo (bot.) mistletoe (Viscum); mistelbero berry of mistletoe.
misterio (also antiq., eccl.) mystery; misteriala relating to mysteries; misterioza, misteriatra mysterious.
mistika, mistik(ul)o mystic; mistikeso, mistikismo mysticism.
mistradukar (tr.) to mistranslate, to translate wrongly.
misuzar (tr.) to misuse, make bad use of, waste.
mito myth.
mitamburo tambourine. V. exp.: Pro ke tamburo (ed anke tamburino) havas du feli, esas naturala indikar per «mitamburo» la instrumento, qua havas un felo; IV-511.
miteno mitten; mi miteno a mitten which leaves the fingers bare. Def.: Ganto en qua nur la grosa fingro esas separita e la qua ceteri unionita; III-327
mitologio mythology; mitologiisto mythologist.
mitro (eccl.) miter (mitre).? DEFIRS
mitralio grape-shot, canister, shrapnel; mitraliagar, mitraliopafar (tr.) to fire grapeshot, shrapnel at or on.
mitraliosomachine-gun; (ancient) mitrailleuse.

mixar (tr.) to mix, mingle, blend (ulo kun ulo); inter mixar to intermix (uli); mixar su to intervene in, meddle; mixar karti shuffle cards; mixo, mixuro mixture, blend, medly; mixajo miscellanea, miscellany; mixolinea (geom.) mixtilineal; mixacheso promiscuousness. Ex.: Mixar l’aquo kun la vino. Mixar (E. blend) kolori. Mixar diversa flori en buketo.Mixar su en l’aferi di altru. Me mixas klor-acido kun nitrat-acido (e me intermixas la du acido).
mizantrop(ul)o misanthrope: hater of mankind.
mizerar (intr.) to be in misery (because of poverty, destitution, or unhappiness or pain); mizero misery, wretchedness, want, sore need, distress.

mizerikordio mercy, mercifulness; mizerikordioza, mizerikordiema merciful, compassionate, clement; sen mizerikordia unmerciful. Def.: Kompato (di Deo) qua pardonas a pekanto; III-327. Ex. Deala mizerikordio. Klamar mizerikordio ad ulu. Ta homo esas senmizerikordia.
mnemoniko mnemonics: art or system for developing the memory.
mobilizar (tr., milit.) to mobilize (troops).

moblo a piece of furniture: any movable object serviceable or use or decoration of an apartment; moblaro (set, collection) furniture; moblizar to furnish (a house, room, etc. with furniture); moblizitadomo, chambro, lojeyo furnished house, room, lodging; moblifar to make furniture.

modomode: a passing usage which depends upon taste, caprice; fashion, style; (gram.) mood (indicative, imperative, etc.); (philos., mus.) mode; (jur.) modus; modala (log.) modal; modaleso (log.) modality; segun la modo, segun moda according to the mode, in the fashion, fashionable; vestizar ulu segun la modo;to dress someone in the fashion: modo anciena old fashion.

modelo model (of a machine, etc.): copy or standard to be followed; modelatra standard, exemplary; Solomon konstruktis la templo segun la modelo di la tabernaklo Solomon built the temple according to the model of the tabernacle; el posturas kom modelo por skultisto she acts as a model for a sculptor; modelo skribita a written copy; ilua vivo esas modelo di vertuo his life is a pattern of virtue; (cf. shablono, imitajo, moduro, modelajo).

moderar (tr.) to moderate: keep within bonds (passions, zeal, ardour, etc.); to abate (a price), reduce (one’s expenses); mitigate (a sentence); moderema temperate; moderilo governor, regulator (of speed); modere moderately; senmodereso immoderation. Ant.: acelerar, augmentar.
moderna modern; -igar to modernize.

modesta modest: not bold or presumptuous; not boastful or obtrusive; (N.B. «modest» in the sense of observing sex proprieties is translated by pudoroza, chasta, decanta). V. exp.: vid. diskreta. Ant.: Superba, pretendema, arogema, vanitatoza, fatua.
modifikar (tr.) to modify: make partial changes in (cf. chanjar); modifikivo (gram.) a modifying or qualifying word. Ex.: Modifikar lego, frazo, puniso.
modiliono* (arch.) modillion.
modlar (tr., sculpt.) to make a model (in clay, wax) of something from which a statue or other work is to be executed or enlarged.
modulo (arch.) module; (math.) modulus.
modulacar (tr.) to modulate: pass from one key to another without break in melody; to inflect, vary ( the voice in speaking).
«mogul» (oriental title) mogul.
Mohamedana, Mohamedano Mahometan, Mohammedan, Musselman; Mohamedanismo Mahometanism, Islamism.
mohero (fabric) mohair.
mokar to laugh at: ridicule, deride, mock, rally, gibe, scoff; moketar to banter, chaff; mok(ad)o mockery, derision, jeer; mokoklamo hue and cry.
mokasino* moccasin: an Indian shoe.

mola soft: easily yielding to pressure, not hard; (cf. dolca); (of muscles) flabby (cf. laxa); (of meat) tender; (of fruits) mellow; molacha flimsy, flabby; moligar to soften; (fig.) to mollify; moligiva emollient; ovi mole koquita soft-cooked eggs. Ant.: harda.
molara (dento) molar, grinder (tooth).
moldar (intr.) to turn, grow mouldy.
molekulo molecule.
moleskino(fabric) moleskin.

molestar (tr.) to molest, pester, annoy, bother. V. exp.: Molestar signifikas volata tedado per tormenteti o persekuteti. La vorto bone tradukas la F. brimer (E. to play jokes on), qua esas molestado impozita kom probo a la novici en armeo, lerneyo. Anke on povas dicar: «la dogano esas konstanta molestado por la voyajanti»; III-35.
molio mole, jetty (used as a harbor (harbour) breakwater).
molibdo* (chem.) molybdenum.
moloso a species of watch-dog (Canis familiaris molossus); (pros.) Molosian metre.
moltono (fabric) molleton: swanskin, canton flannel.
molusko mollusk.
momento momentum.
monado (philos., zool.) monad.

monak(ul)o monk, friar; monakala, monakatra monastic, monachal, monkish; monakino nun; monakeso (condition, state) monasticism, monkhood; monakismo (system, doctrine) monasticism; monakeyo monastery, convent.
monarko monarch; monarkala monarchal: relating to monarchs.
monarkio monarchy; monarkiala monarchal: relating to monarchies; (cf. monarkala). ?DEFIRS

monato month; monatsalario month;s pay; omnamonate, monata every month, monthly; camonate (during, in) this month; po monato, singla monate by the month, so much a month; mi monata half-monthly, twice a month.

mondo (general sense) the world (cf. tero); mondumo the world: society, people; mondumo eleganta, alta world of fashion, smart set, high-life; mondalamundane; mondumema worldly-minded; mondumala relating to society; relating to good manners; mondumajo a worldly thing, vanity; mondumanulo man of the world; umaneso worldliness.
monero (zool.) moner(on).

moneto (of gold, silver, copper) coin, cash, change, specie; (fig.) currency; (cf. pekunio); monetopeco a coin; monetpapero paper money: which takes the place of coin (cf. bankobilieto); monetala monetary; monetigar to monetize: put into circulation, give a standard value to in currency; monetifar to coin, mint into money; to raise money; monetifisto coiner; monetifeyo, moneterio mint; monetuyo a purse.
monismo* (philos.) monism.
monisto* monist.
monitoro (nav.) monitor.
monodroma* (math.) monodromic.
monofiletika* (bot.) monophyletic.
monoftongo* (gram.) monophthong: a single vowel sound; a combination of two vowels pronounced as one.
monogama monogamic; monogam(ul)o monogamist.
monogena* (math.) monogenic, monogenetic.
monografio monograph.
monogramo monogram.
monoika* (bot.) monoecious.
monoklo monocle, single eye-glass. Def.: Unika aparta okulvitro; V-1.
monoklina (bot.) monoclinous; (cryst.) monoclinic.
monokordo (mus. and acous.) mono-chord.
monokotiledona, monoo (bot.) monocotyledon(ous).
monokroma monochrome; monokromajo (paint) monochrome picture; camaieu. Def.: (monokrom-ajo) Pikturo per un sola koloro, plu o min klara; VI-480.
monolita, monolito monolith(ic).
monologo monologue, soliloquy.
monomanio (med.) monomania: insanity upon one particular subject (cf. manio); monomaniika, monomaniiko monomaniac(al).
monomio, monomiala (alg.) monomial.
monopolo monopoly; monopoligar to monopolize; monopolemo, monopoliganto, monopolero, monopolisto monopolist.
monosilaba monosyllabic.
monosperma* (bot.) monospermous.
monoteismo monotheism.
monoteisto monotheist.
monotona monotonous; monotoneso monotony.
monotropo* (math.) monotropa.
monstro (pr. and fig.) monster; monstra, monstrala, monstratra monstrous, enormous; monstrajo (object or act) monstrosity.

monto mount, mountain; monteto hill, hillock, knoll; montaro, montokateno mountain range; montoza mountainous; montetoza hilly; monto Etna Mt. Etna; Venusmonto (anat.) mons veneris; montopinto mountain peak (the point); (cf. admonte).
montanto upright: piece of any framework, wood or iron; stanchion, beam, post, side-piece (of a ladder).

montrar (tr.) to show, exhibit: make to see or know; montrinda worthy of showing, presentable; montristo showman; montrar rara libro to show a rare book; montrez a me ta homulo show me that man; montrar kurajo to show courage; (cf. manifestar, expozar, indikar, prizentar, aparar).
monumento monument.
mopso pug-dog.
moqueto moquette: a kind of velvet carpeting; Wilton carpeting.

mori manners, habits, conduct considered from the moral point of view; (cf. etiko); bona mori good morals, habits or customs; morala habitual, customary: relating to mori (N.B. not conforming to the rules of right conduct, righteousness. A moral man = etikala homulo; cf. IV-233); moralisto: one who studies the «mori». Def.: Kustumi (di persono o lando), natural od aquirita, relate lia boneso o maledeso por la konduto di vivo.

morbo disease, malady, distemper: the illness itself; (for state, condition, ill person, cf. malada, morbeso); morboza diseased; morbala morbid: relating to the disease; morbifanta, morbiva morbific, pathogenic. Ex.: Kancero esas un de la maxim danjeroza morbi; Morbala simtomi. V .exp.: Me audas, ke Sro. X. esas malada (E. sick, ill). Yes, il havas la morbo (E. disease) di Bright. Nuntempe esas multe maladeso (E. sickness) en nia urbo.
morbilo (med.) measles.
mordar (tr.) to bite (cf. rodar); mordetar to nibble; mordanta, mordema biting; (fig.) mordant, caustic, sarcastic, poignant.
morelo (bot.) morel: an edible fungus (Morchella esclenta).
moreno (geol.) moraine.
morfino morphia, morphine,
morfogena* (biol.) morphogenic.
morfogenezo* (biol.) morphogenesis.
morfologio morphology.
morfoso* (biol.) morphosis.

morge tomorrow, (la) morga dio, morgo the next day, day after; morge matinetomorrow morning; posmorge (day) after tomorrow; til morge until tomorrow; sep dii pos morge a week from tomorrow. Ex.: li lektos la libro morge. Se me ne venos morge, takaze me venos posmorge.
morganatika morganatic.
morilio andiron, fire-dog.
morso bit (of a bridle); (fig.) curb, check, restraint.

mortar (intr., lit. and fig.) to die, cease to live, depart this life; (of fire) to go out; (of movement) to come to an end; mortigar to deprive of life; cause to die, kill, execute, put to death (by natural or artificial means); (cf. ocidar, asasinar, senkapigar, masakrar); morteskar to be dying, be on the point of death; morto death, decease; mortado mortality; mortanto, mortonto dying person, moribund person; mortinta dead, defunct; mortopunto point of death; mortopuniso death penalty; mortala death; mortiva mortal: subject to death; mortiveso liability to death; mortigive malada mortally sick; mortigo killing, execution; mortigisto executioner; mortiganta, mortiva mortal, deadly: which causes death; (as a disease, wound); stone mortinta stone dead; naske mortinta born dead stillborn; mortar naturale to die a natural death; mortale vundita mortally wounded; mortigive mortala paleso deathly pallor; esar (balde) mortonta to be at the point of death, at death’s door; mortar ye la mondumo; to be dead to the world; mortintala domo mortuary; depoz, expozeyo di mortinti morgue.
mortadelo Bologna sausage.
mortero mortar: a building cement.
mortezo (carp.) mortise; mortezizar to cut a mortise in.
mortifikar (tr., rel. and fig.) to subdue the passions and appetites by severe discipline; (N.B. for sense of «to humiliate», cf. shamigar, vexar).
moruo (ich.) cod (-fish) (Gadus morrhua); sika moruo stockfish; dried (unsalted) cod; sika salmoruo dried salted cod; oleo ek moruhepato cod-liver oil.
moruso (bot.) mulberry; morusiero mulberry tree (genus: Morus).
morvo (vet.) glanders.
moso cabin-boy, sea-apprentice, ship-boy.

mosko (scent) musk; -izita m. scented; moskanado m. duck; (Anas moschata); moskocervo m. deer (Moschus moschiferus); moskobovo m. ox (Ovibus moschatus); moskomusareno m. shrew, sondeli (Myogale moschata); moskorato m. rat (Fiber zibethicus); moskoskarabeo m. beetle (Ceromby moschatus).
moskeo mosque.
moskito (ent.) mosquito; para moskito mosquito net.
mosto must: unfermented grape-juice.
moto motto (of a book, a chapter).
motacilo (orni.) wagtail (Motacilla).
moteto (mus.) motet.

motivo motive: that which excites to action, determines choice; (mus.) motif; motivizar to state the motive or grounds of (an opinion, act); (fig.) to justify; plendo motivo reason for complaint, grievance; sen motiva gratuitous: without proof or motive (cf. gratuita); sen motiva supozajo gratuitous supposition; il motivizis sua refuzo he stated the grounds for his refusal.
motoro (mechanical) motor: moving power, that which imparts motion; motorveturo motor vehicle; gazolin motoro gasoline motor.

movar (tr., intr.) to move, set in motion, stir, propel; mov(ad)o movement, motion; movanta moving; moviva motive, propelling, driving; movebla movable; movebleso mobility; movopovo moving power, propelling force; movo alternanta alternating movement; ne movebla immovable.
movimento (mus.) tempo, movement, time.

moyeno means, medium (through which a thing is done); instrumentality; moyeni (material) means, resources; (math.) means; moyenacho (poor) expedient; moyeni legitima legitimate means; per la moyeno by means (of); kontributar segun sua moyeni contribute according to one’s means; vivo moyeni means of subsistence or existence; trovar la moyeno facar ulo to find the means to do something.
mozaiko mosaic (work).

muar (intr.) to moult, mew; shed or cast off hair (if dogs), feathers (of birds), horns (of deer), outer layer of skin (of serpents), and the like which are replaced by new growth; to break, change (voice at puberty); vocomuo change of voice. Def.: Chanjar pelo, pili, plumi, ye determinita tempi o periodi; III-606.
muaro moire: a watered fabric, as watered silk.
mucilajo (bot.) (plant-) mucilage; (N.B. for the adhesive substance, cf. gluo). Def.: Humoro vikoza qua trovesas en ula planti; IV-586.
muevo (orni.) gull, sea-gull (genus: Larus).
mufo muff (for hands); (tech.) casing, box.
muflo (chem.) muffle. Def.: Speco di vazo (ek argilo) en qua on pozas objekti submisenda nedirete a l’efiko di la fairo; III-530.
muflono (zool.) mouflon; species of wild sheep (Ovis Musimon).
«mufti» mufti: Mohammedan official.
mujar (intr.) to bellow, roar (winds, waves, thunder, cannon); (cf. bramar).
muko mucus; mukozo mucus membrane (cf. pituito, mucilajo). Def.: Humoro normale sekretaca da la membrani dicata mukozi; IV-585.
mulo, mulino, mululo mule; mul(dukt)isto muleteer.
mulato, mulatulo, mulatino mulatto; (cf.mestico, hibrido). Def.: Genetito da blankulo e negrino (o negro e blankino); V-33.

muldar (tr.) to form a mold (mould) of, as in sand, in which to make a casting; (fig.) -ar su to mold, model oneself. V. exp.: En giserio, on unesme muldas: to esas ago donar justa formo ad la sablo o l’argilo en qua on varsos la fuzita metalo. Po la muldo on uzas la muldilo ek ligno, fero, e.c. Duesme on gisas la fuzita metalo en la mulduro; III-82.

multa (of number) many, numerous; (of quantity) much; multo a lot, a large quantity; multi many (in number); multa homuli many men; multa vino much wine; multeso, multopleso multiplicity; multopla, multo manifold, multiple; (plu) multigar to multiply: make more numerous (for math. sense, cf. multiplikar); multigo multiplication; multeskar to become more numerous; multatempe many a time; multaforma multiform; multaflora multiflorous: many-flowered; multe plu bone much better, a great deal better; multasorta, speca many kinds of, many species of; multakolora multi-colo(u)red, many colored; plu o min multe more or less. Ant. Poka.
multiforma* (math.) multiform.
multiplikar (tr., arith.) to multiply; multiplikendo multiplicand.
multipola* (math.) multipolar.
muluro (arch.) moulding; (cf. kornico).
mumio mummy; mumiigar to mummify.
mungar (su) to blow one’s nose, to wipe one’s nose.
municiono, municioni ammunition, munition (of war); municionfurgono caisson.
muliero woman (adult); (cf. viro, homino).
municipo municipality; municipestro mayor (of a city); (cf. urbestro).
muntar (tr., tech.) to put together, assemble, set up, mount (a machine, a gem). V. exp.: On asemblas planki o peci, on ne muntas li. On muntas mashino o karpenturo, asemblante lua peci; IV-598.
muro wall; murego thick or large wall (as of a city, a fort); murala mural; murizar, murklozar to wall up, immure; murarmoro cupboard (in a wall);murpapero wallpaper.
mureno (ich.) muraena, moray (Muraena helena).

murmurar (intr.) to murmur: make a low, continued noise; (of water) to purl; (of wind) to breathe, whisper, rustle; (of bees) to hum; murmur(ach)ar (tr.) to mumble, mutter: utter indistinctly; (N.B. for sense of «to whisper» cf. susurar).
muso mouse; musea, musgriza m. colo(u)red, m. gray (grey) (colored); mustruo m. hole; museyo m. nest; muskaptilo m. trap.
musareno (zool.) shrew-mouse (genus: Sorex).
musho (ent.) fly; musheto small fly, midge; mushkaptilo f. catcher; para musho f. screen; mushsnapero* (orni.) flycatcher (Muscicapa).
musko (bot.) moss; muskoza mossy, moss-grown.
muskado nutmeg; muskadiero nutmeg tree (Myristica fragrans).
muskato muscat grape; muskatvino muscatel (wine).
musketo matchlock (musket); musketiero musketeer, mousquetaire.
musketono musketoon: an ancient musket.
muskulo (anat.) muscle; muskulala muscular (system, etc.); muskuloza muscular: brawny; muskularo musculature; muskuleso muscularity.
muslo common (or, edible) mussel (Mytilus edulis): (cf. molusko).
muslino (fabric) muslin.

mustar (intr.)must, to have to, to be under the nesessity of, be obliged; (past tense) had to; me mustas ridar, vidante ta spektaklo I had to laugh, seeing that spectacle (i.e., I could not do otherwise). V. exp.: Mustar expresas neceseso absoluta (sen-kondiciona) e nerezistebla; VI-487; kp. darfar, oportar. Ex.: Sur ta glitiganta planko-sulo, me mustis falar. Quante richa il mustas esar. Me mustas facar equivalas: esas necesa ke me facez. Quon on mustas facar por enirar en la cielo? Il ne povas venar kun me, il mustas laborar.
mustardo (condiment) mustard; mustarduyo mustard pot.
muta, mut(ul)o dumb, mute: destitute of the power of speech (cf. tacanta); mutega, stonemuta stone dumb.
mutaco (biol.) mutation.
mutilar (tr.) to mutilate, maim. Ex.: Mutilar membro di la korpo. (fig.) Mutilar la verseso, la poemo.

mutono a sheep; mutoni sheep; (fig.) small, compact masses of white fleecy clouds (which move across the sky like a flock of sheep); mutonino ewe; mutonulo ram; mutonkarno mutton; mutonatra sheep-like; woolly, fleecy; mutoneyo, mutonstablo sheep-fold; mutonfelo sheepskin; mutonshultro shoulder of mutton; pastoro di mutoni shepherd.

mutuala mutual. Ex.: Societo di mutual sokurso (E. benefit society). Mutuala asekurerio. V. exp.: Mutuala, reciproka: Mutuala aplikesas nur a la sociala institucuri di «reciproka» helpo, sokurso, e.c.; IV-162.
muzo (myth., also fig.) Muse.
muzeo museum,

muzelo (anat.) snout, muzzle (of animals); (fig.) pout, pouting; facar muzelo to pout, stick out the lips; muzelligar to muzzle; muzelligilo a muzzle; muzelfloro (bot.) snapdragon (Antirrhinum). Def.: La nazo e la boko di bestii, en qui ta du parti esas salienta (hundo, porko, e.c.); III-10.

muzikar (intr.) to play music; muzikigar to set to m.; muzikajo written music, score; muzikala musical, relating to m.; muzikema musical: fond of playing m.; muzikamanta m. loving; muzikisto, muzikero musician. Note: A list of musical terms and abbreviations may be found IV-328-330.
myelo spinal-marrow, -cord.
myelino (anat.) myelin.
myelito (med.) myelitis: inflammation of spinal cord.
nabo nave; hub of a wheel.
nabeto (bot.) rape (Brassica rapa oleifera); nabetoleo rape oil.
nabobo* nabob. Def.: Princo di India; metafore, richega viro; VII-280.

naciono nation; nacionala national; nacionano a native, national; member of a nation; nacionaligar to nationalize (an industry, etc.); nacionanigar to naturalize (cf. civitanigar); nacionalismo devotion to or advocacy of a nation; national interest or unity; nacioneso nationality (of a nation as a whole); nacionaleso, nacionaneso nationality (of an individual); nacionalista, nacionisto nationalist(ic).
nadiro (astron.) nadir.
nafto naptha.
naftalino napthaline.
naiva naïve: unaffectedly simple: ingenuous; artless; naivajo act of native simplicity; naivacha silly.
nakarata, nakarato nacarat: orange-red colo(u)r.
naktigalo (orni.) nightingale (genus: Luscinia).

nam (conj.) for (= because, but in a less immediate and explicit way than pro ke. Introduces a sentence or subordinate clause which adduces reason, proof or justification). Esas matino, nam la uceli kantas it is morning for (not because: pro ke) the birds are singing. Ex.: Vu ne trovos il en la domo, nam me jus vidis il en la strado. Vu ne povas vidar il, nam il esas departinta de longe. Lavez vua manui, nam li esas sordida. Me ne povas amar ilu, nam il odias me. Ni irez lente adheme, nam balde esos nokto. V. exp.: Nam, pro ke: Pro ke introduktas dependanta propoziciono, qua kontenas motivo o pruvo por la chefa propoziciono prieranta o sequanta: nam introduktas chefa frazo, qua kontenas anke motivo o pruvo, ma nur por preiranta frazo, o tacita penso. Ex.: Pro ke pluvas, me ne ekiros. Me ne ekiros nam pluvas; III-223; cf. or. Ta du konjuncioni interdistingesas precize quale Angla for e because. La Angla linguisto Sweet skribas pri li tale: «La du precipua konjuncioni kauzala esas pro ke, qua konstatas nemediata e direte aganta kauzo, e nam, qua ajuntas expliko o motivo, ofte kom quaza posa penso; ex.: ni kunprenis nia parapluvi, pro ke ni timas ke pluvos; nam la barametro falis de kelka tempo. Konseque, nam uzesas libere pos pauzo ed esas do nur mi-konjunciono (konjunciono koordinanta); IV-524; kp. Talmey’s Text Book, p. 113.
nano dwarf.
nankino (fabric) nankeen, nankin.
napo turnip (Brassica Napus esculenta).

naracar (tr.) to narrate, relate, tell (something that happened, a true incident); naracar sua historio to tell one’s history; naraco pri batalio* narrative of (or, about) a battle. V. exp.: Naracar ne esas samsenca kam rakontar; naraco esas prefere historiala, do vera; rakonto esas prefere imaginala, do desvera o fingita; ex.: «il naracis lua historio, qua semblas feala rakonto»; II-485-6.
narciso (bot.) narcissus, daffodil; (genus: Narcissus); (cf. jonquilo).
nardo (bot.) spikenard (East Indian: Nardostachys Jatamansi); nardounguento nard (ointment).
narkotar (intr.) to be in a state of narcosis; narkoto narcosis; narkotigar to narcotize; narkotigiva, narkotivo narcotic.
narvalo narwhal (Monodon monoceros).
naso bownet, eel-trap (for fish); hoopnet (for birds).

naskar (intr.) to be born; nasko, naskepoko birth, nativity; naskala natal; naskigar to give birth to (cf. genitar); naske blinda blind from birth; naskanta nascent; naskala yuro (od,naskoyuro) birthright; naskinta nove new-born (child, etc.); -into unesma first-born child; (cf. seniora); naske poeto a poet by birth, a born poet; naskolando land of birth, fatherland (cf. patrio); naskoloko birthplace; naskennaskinto a native; kunnaskinto congenital.
natar (intr.) to swim (of living beings); naterio natatorium.
natro (chem.) sodium; natrokloro chloride of sodium.

naturo (all senses) nature; naturala (also mus.) natural; naturale naturally; naturala lego natural law; naturalismo (philos., art) naturalism; naturalisto (philos., art) naturalist; naturciencisto naturalist: one versed in natural history; naturkolora (of wood, etc.) not colored, of natural colo(u)r.
naufrajar (intr.) to be shipwrecked; naufrajo (ship)wreck; naufrajanto, naufrajinto shipwrecked person, castaway.
nautilo (zool.) nautilus.

nauzear (intr.) to feel nauseated, be sick to the stomach, be qualmish; nauze(ad)o nausea, qualm, retching; nauzeigar to nauseate (cf. insipidigar, repugnar, vomar); nauzeiganta nauseous; (fig.) loathsome, disgusting.

navo (nav.) vessel: (merchant-) ship (cf. militnavo); nave (of a church); navaro shipping (collect.), fleet; naveto (fig. eccl.) incense-box; (weaver’s) shuttle; navala nautical; navano member of a ship’s company; navero, navisto seaman, mariner, sailor; navestro master of a (merchant-) ship; navo triferdeka a three decker (ship); komercnavo, varnavo merchant-man; vapor navo steamer; me iris nave (de Hamburg ad Bordeaux) I went by ship (from H. to B.); la kapitano restis ennave the captain (of a warship) remained on board; navatra osto scaphoid bone (cf. tarso); navoida osto scaphoid bone (of carpal bones).

navigar (tr., intr.) to navigate, sail (on); navigarto (art of) navigation, seamanship; naviganta viro seafaring man; navigala nautical: relating to navigation;navigebla navigable; fora navigado foreign trade; rivo navigo coasting;.
nayado (myth.) naiad, water-nymph.

nazo nose; nazala nasal; nazalo (gram.) a nasal (sound, letter); nazaligar (gram.) to nasalize; nazfetida a stinking nose; (med.) affected with ozaena; nazguto a nose-drop, snot, snivel; nazkataro cold in the head; nazpeco nose-piece (serving as protection); nazparolar to speak through the nose; naztruo nostril; (of whales) blow-hole; naztuko handkerchief; nazbinoklo nose glasses; facar longa nazo (ad, kontre) (fig.) to laugh at; nazo kontre nazo nose to nose (fig.) face to face.

ne (adv.) not; ne plus no more; ne multo not much; tote ne not at all, by no means, not in the least; ne tam multe not so much; me anke ne nor I also; ne for not far from; ne nur not only; ne tante stupida not so stupid; ne male not badly; ne ja not yet. Note: As distinguishable from des in word composition, ne carries a less forceful sense of negation, implying merely absence of the positive quality rather than the absolute negation; ex.: nefacila difficult = not easy; desfacila difficult = arduous, laborious.
neacentizita unaccented.
neaceptebla unacceptable.
neacesebla (of persons, places) unapproachable, inaccessible.
neadmisebla inadmissible.
neago, neagemeso inactivity; neaganta inactive; neagema (tendency) inactive; indolent, lazy.
neaktiva inactive.
neakurata unpunctual, not prompt.
nealienebla inalienable.
nealterebla unalterable: unmodified; unadulterated.
neamansita untamed.
neaplikebla inapplicable.
neaprobar (tr.) to disapprove: not to approve (ulo).
neapta inapt, unfit.
neatakebla unassailable; (fig.) unimpeachable, irreproachable.
neatencoza, neema inattentive, unmindful.
neaudita unheard (of).
neblamebla blameless.
nebular (impers.) to be foggy, misty, hazy; nebuloza, nebulatra foggy, misty, nebulous (cf. nebuloza); (fig.) obscure, not intelligible; nebulizar to cover with fog; nebulpluvar to drizzle.
nebuloso (astron.) nebula.
necerta uncertain.

necesa necessary, indispensable requisite (cf. bezonata); necesajo a necessary thing, the needful; necesigar necessitate. Ex.: Esas necesa konsequajo. Respirado esas necesa por la vivo. Ne esas necesa parolar pri to. Ant.: superflua, neutila.
necesanta incessant (cf. sencesa).
nechanjebla unchangeable, unalterable, immutable.
nechasta unchaste, lewd, immodest.
necirkoncizita, neito uncircumsized (person).
necivilizita uncivilized.
nedechifrebla undecipherable.
nedecidema, neiva irresolute, indecisive; neita undecided (of acts).
nedefensebla indefensible, untenable.
nedefinita undefined, indefinite.
nedelikata indelicate.
nedependo independence.
nedeskriptebla indescribable.
nedestruktebla indestructible.
nedeterminebla indeterminable.
nedevocoza undevout, irreligious.
nedicebla unutterable, unspeakable.
nedigestebla indigestible.
nedireta indirect (cf. mediata).
nediskreta indiscreet; neeso, neajo (quality, act) indiscretion.
nedisponebla indisposable, unavailable.
nedistingita indistinct (voice, etc.); neebla undistinguishable; neante, neite indifferently (without distinction).
nedividita undivided; neebla indivisible.
nedocila intractable.
nedomtebla indomitable, untamable, ungovernable.
nedormado, neiveso sleeplessness, wakefulness, insomnia.
nedubebla indubitable.
neduranta, neiva not lasting, transient, transitory.
needitita, neajo unpublished (book, paper).
neefacebla indelible, ineffaceable.
neefikanta, neiva inefficacious, ineffective, unavailing, inefficient.
neego (philos.) the non-ego, the external world.
neegala unequal, (cf. nepara).
neelektebla (polit.) ineligible.
neequitatoza inequitable.
neeroriva infallible (church, etc.); not capable of erring (cf. infalibla, nefaliiva).
neesperebla, neita unhoped for, unlooked for; (cf. neexpektata).
neetikala, neajo immoral (act.) ; ne(ul)o immoral person.
neevaluebla invaluable, inappreciable.
neevitebla inevitable, unavoidable.
neexakta (of objects) inaccurate, incorrect, inexact (calculation, news, etc.); neajo an inaccuracy.
neexekutebla impracticable, unfeasible; neita unexecuted.
neexercita unexercised, unpractised, unexerted, undrilled.
neexhaustebla inexhaustible.
neexisto non-existence.
neexkuzebla inexcusable, unwarrantable; (cf. nejustifikebla, nepardonebla).
neexpektata, neita unexpected, unthought of, unlooked for; (cf. neesperita).
neexperta inexperienced, inexpert, unpractised.
neexplorita unexplored, uninvestigated; neebla inscrutable, unfathomable.
neexplotata, neita(of mines, etc.) unexploited, unworked; (land) untilled, uncultivated.
neexplikebla unexplainable, inexplicable, unaccountable, singular; neita unexplained.
neexpresebla inexpressible, ineffable, unutterable.
neextingebla inextinguishable, unquenchable.
neextirpebla ineradicable.
nefacebla impracticable (cf. neexekutebla).
nefacila difficult: not easy (cf. Note under ne).
nefaliiva unfailing, unerring, infallible (cf. neeroriva, infalibla).
nefatigebla indefatigable, untiring, unwearied.
nefekunda (of living beings)infertile, barren, sterile (cf. nefertila).
neferma unstable, not solid; weak.
nefertila (of ground, inanimate things) infertile, barren (cf. nefekunda).
nefidela unfaithful, untrue, disloyal.
nefinita unended, unfinished, indefinite (without end); (cf. nedefinita, infinita).
nefixa movable.
neflexebla (phys., moral) inflexible; inexorable, unbending.
nefrito* (med.) nephritis.

negar (tr.) to deny: declare untrue or non-existing; (cf. renegar); neg(ad)odenial, denying, negation; negilo (gram.) a negative (word); negala negative: relation to negation; neganta, negiva denying; expressing negation, negatory; negebla deniable; kad vu negas ke vu dicis to do you deny that you said that? Ant.: afirmar.
negastigema inhospitable.
negativa, negativo (math., photog., elec.) negative.

neglijar (tr.) to neglect: to treat carelessly, slight, be remiss (in the performance of a duty, task, care of health, peson, etc.); neglijo negligence; neglijado (habitual) neglect; neglijeso (state of) neglect; neglijanta, neglijema negligent, neglectful, remiss, careless; neglijebla negligible, trifling, unimportant. Ant.: sorgar.
neglijeo negligee, undress, dishabille: unceremonious attire.
negociar (tr.) to negotiate: to procure, or arrange for, by negotiating. Ex.: Negociar ligo atakala e defensala; Negociado pri ula afero grava, pri mariajo.
negra negr(ul)o negro; negrino negress; negracha nigger; negrovendado slave trade; negrovendisto slaver. Ant.: (negr(ul)o), blank(ul)o
negracioza ungraceful.
negratitudo unfratitude, thanklessness; neoza unthankful, ingrate.
neguvernebla ungovernable.
nehabila unskilful, inept, awkward.
nehabitata uninhabited.
nehomala inhuman: non-human (cf. nehumana).
nehonesta dishonest, unfair, underhand, discreditable.
nehumana inhuman: cruel.
neimitebla inimitable.
neinteligenta unintelligent, stupid.
neinterruptita uninterrupted.
neinterveno non-intervention
nejurinta, neinto unsworn (person).
nejusta improper, wrong; (cf. neyusta).
nejustifikebla unjustifiable, unwarrantable.
nek … nek neither … nor; me povas nek enirar nek ekirar I can get neither in nor out; il drinkas nek biro nek vino he drinks neither beer nor wine.
nekaptebla uncapturable, impregnable, unseizable.
nekareebla indispensable.
nekombatebla indisputable.
nekombustebla incombustible.
nekomoda inconvenient.
nekomparebla incomparable: (fig.) matchless, unequalled, peerless.
nekompleta incomplete.
nekomprenebla incomprehensible, unintelligible.
nekonceptebla inconceivable.
nekoncianta unconscious.
nekonciliebla incompatible, irreconcilable.
nekonquestebla impregnable.
nekonsequo (log.) incoherence, inconsequence, inconsistency.
nekonstanta inconstant, fickle, unsteady, flighty, changeable (cf. variema).
nekonstitucala unconstitutional.
nekontebla countless, innumerable.
nekontenta dissatisfied.
nekorpala incorporeal.
nekoruptebla (phys., mor.) incorruptible.
nekredebla incredible, past belief; neanto, neero unbeliever, infidel.
nekrobioso* (biol.) necrobiosis.
nekrologo necrology: obituary review of (distinguished) persons who have died within a certain length of time.
nekromancio necromancy: pretended divination by aid of spirits; black art; (fig.) magic; nekromanciar to practise necromancy.
nekropolonecropolis, city of the dead, large cemetery.
nekroso* (med.) necrosis.
nektaro* (myth., bot., fig.) nectar.
nektario* (bot.) nectary.
nekunmezurebla incommensurable.
nekustumala uncustomed, uwonted (hono(u)r, etc.) unusual, unfamiliar (object); neanta (of persons) unaccustomed.
nelacerebla untearable.
nelauta low (voice), under one’s breath.
nelegala illegal, unlawful.
nelektebla unreadable, illegible.
nelezita unhurt, uninjured.
nelogikala illogical.
nemanjebla uneatable.
nemediata immediate: proximate; direct (without intervention of another object, cause or agency); nee directly (cf. quik, direta).
nemeritata, neita unmerited, undeserved, uncalled for.
nemezurebla immeasurable, inappreciable.
nemortiva, neivo everlasting, immortal; neiveso immortality; neigar, nemortiva to immortalize.
nemodesta immodest: not boastful (cf. nepudoroza).
nemovanta motionless, immobile; neebla immovable; neebleso immobility.
nenavigebla unnavigable, unseaworthy.
nenegebla undeniable.
nenio* nenia. Def.: Kanto o lamento funerala, en l’antiqua mori.
nenobela plebean; ne(ul)ocommoner.
nenociva innocuous, harmless.
nenormala anomalous, irregular (cf. anomala).
nenufaro nenuphar: nenuphär: the great white water-lily of Europa (Nymphaea albl or, Nuphar).
neobediema not obedient, insubordinate.
neofensiva inoffensive.
neologismo neologism.
neono:* (chem.) neon.
neoportuna innoportune, unseasonable.
neordinara uncommon, unusual (cf. extraordinara).
neorganika inorganic.
neovitalismo* neovitalism.
nepacigebla implacable, inexorable.
nepacienta impatient; neesoimpatience; neigar, neeskar to make, to become impatient.
nepalpebla impalpable.
nepara not even, odd (of numbers)
nepardonebla unpardonable; neema unrelenting, implacable, pitiless; (cf. neexkuzebla).
nepartisana unpartisan, impartial; neaneso impartiality.
nepekiva impeccable.
nepenetrebla impenetrable, impermeable, impervious (cf. nepermeebla).
neperceptebla imperceptible, undiscernible.
neperfekta imperfect; neigebla imperfectible.
neperisiva imperishable, everlasting.
nepermeebla impermeable (cf. nepenetrebla).
nepersonala (gram., philos.) impersonal.
neperturebla imperturbable.
neplana uneven: not level.
nepolita impolite, uncourteous, uncivil.
nepolitika impolitic (in affairs of state).
neponderebla imponderable.
nepopulara unpopular.
neposibla impossible; neeso, neajo (quality, act) impossibility.
nepoto, nepotulo, nepotino grandchild; pos nepotulo great-grandson.
nepotismo nepotism.
nepotenta impotent: powerless (cf. impotenta).
nepovo, neeso inability, incapacity.
neprevido, neemeso wanting foresight, improvidence; neanta, neema improvident (person); neita unforeseen, unlooked for (thing); neite unawares, napping.
neprobabla improbable, unlikely (cf. neversimila).
neproduktiva, neema unproductive.
neprofunda shallow: (fig.) superficial.
nepronuncebla unpronounceable.
neprudenta imprudent, foolhardy, indiscreet.
Neptunala (geol.) Neptunian.
nepudoroza, neema immodest (in sex proprieties; cf. nemodesta).
nepura impure (cf. nechasta).
neracionala, neoza irrational, unreasonable.
Nereido (myth.) Nereid.
nereala unreal; neigebla unrealizeable.
nerefutebla irrefutable, irrefragable.
neregulala, neoza irregular (cf. nekorekta); neozeso irregularity (cf. neplanajo).
nerekuperebla irrecoverable.
neremediebla incurable (disease) (cf. nesanigebla).
nereparebla (lit. and fig.) irreparable.
nerepresebla irrepressible.
nereprochebla irreproachable.
nerespektoza disrespectful (ad).
neresponsiva irresponsible.
nerezistebla irresistible.

nervo nerve; nervaro nervous system; nervala nervous: relating to the nerves; nervoza, nervoz(ul)o nervous (person); nervozeso nervousness; nervozigar to excite the nerves of (ulu); nervozeskar to grow, become nervous; sen nervigar to unnerve.
nervaturo (bot., ent.) nervure.
nesanigebla (of persons) incurable (cf. neremediebla).
nesaturebla insatiable.
nesekebla indivisible.
nesekura insecure, unsafe.
nesentiva insensetive, unfeeling, impassive; neeble insensibly, imperceptibly.
neseparebla inseparable.
neserioza superficial (mind) not dangerous (wound, etc); (cf. neprofunda, surfacala).
neshanceligebla (lit. and fig.) unshakable, immovable, resolute, steady, firm.
neshirmata unscreened, unsheltered, open.
nesignifiko insignificance (cf. sensignifika, senimporta, sen valora).
neskrupuloza unscrupulous.
nesobra intemperate (in eating and drinking); (cf. nemoderata, nediskreta).
nesociema unsociable.
nesolvebla insoluble (problem, etc.).
nesondebla; (lit. and fig.) unfathomable.
nesonora dull, hollow, toneless, muffled (cf. matida).
nesorgema inattentive, heedless, unmindful, negligent.
nesto (also fig.) (bird-) nest; nestifar to build a nest.
nesubmersebla unsinkable.
nesubmisita unsubdued.
nesuceso non-success, failure.
nesuciema careless, unsolicitous.
nesuficanta insufficient, inadequate.
nesustenebla insupportable, indefensible, untenable.

neta clean, spotless, neat, tidy, natty: without spot, stain, blot, impurity; (of price) net (cf. sentara); netigar to clean, cleanse; nete kopiar to make a fair copy of. Ex.: Neta aquo, plado, denti, manui, (fig.) koncienco. Ant.: sordida, neneta (cf. pura).
netoleranta, neema intolerant; neebla intolerable, insupportable, unbearable, insufferable.
netradukebla untranslatable.
netrairebla impassable.
netranquila (phys., mental) untranquil, unquiet, unagitated, uneasy, restless.
netransaktema intransigent, (esp. in politics: refusing compromise); irreconcilable, uncompromising.
netransitiva (gram.) intransitive.
netushita untouched, intact; neebla untouchable, intangible.
neurono* (anat.) neurone.
neutila useless, needless.

neutra (all senses) neutral, neuter; (la) neutro (gram.) a neuter; (la) neutri (polit.) the neutral powers; neutreso neutrality; neutrigar to neutralize (cf. equalibrar, kompensar). Ex.: Neutra vorto, sexuo, naciono, persono, (chem.) salo.
neuz(ad)o disuse; neata, neita unused, not in use, unutilized, obsolete.
nevo, nevulo, nevino nephew, niece; ponevulo grandnephew.
nevalida invalid; neigar to invalidate, void, vitiate.
nevarianta, neebla, neiva invariable, unchangeable, unalterable.
neveo neve (glacial snow).
nevendebla unsaleable; neita unsold, la nevenditaji goods unsold.
neversimila unlikely, improbable, not plausible (cf. neprobabla).
nevidebla invisible; neita unseen, unpercieved.
nevinkebla unconquerable, invincible, insuperable, insurmountable, overwhelming; neita unvanquished.
neviolacebla inviolable; neata, neita inviolate.
nevolata, neita involuntary (cf. senvola), unwilled.
nevolunta unwilling.
nevralgio neuralgia.
nevrastenio (med.) neurasthenia.
nevrito* (med.) neuritis.
nevrologio* neurology.
nevroptero (ent.) neuropteran.
nevroso (med.) neurosis; nevrosika, nevrosiko neurotic (person).
nevundebla invulnerable.
nevuso nævus: pigmented place on skin, usually congenital; birthmark, mole; nevuso flamea burnt mark, scar of burn.
neyusta unjust, unlawful, unrighteous, unfair (cf. nejusta).
nezeloza lukewarm.
ni we, us (a ni, nin); nia our(s) «Nia Patro»: the Lord’s Prayer, (cf. note under on).
nicho (arch.) niche, nook: recess in a wall (as for a statue or a bed)
nielo niello: a black enamel.
nigelo (bot.) nigella: fennel-flower (genus: Nigella).
nigra black (cf. obskura); nigro black, the colo(u)r itself (cf. negro); nigreso (quality) blackness; nigrigar to blacken, smut; nigreskar to turn black. Ant.: blanka.

nihilo naught, nothing, something non-existent, nonenity (cf. nulo); nihila void; nihileso nothingness, inexistence, nihility; nihilajo a nullity; nihiligar; nihileskar (jur.) to annul, become void; to rescind, cancel; nihiligebla voidable; nihilismo nihilism; nihilisto, nihila nihilist(ic); nihileso di grandeso homalanothingness of human greatness. V. exp: Destruktar, nihiligar por la destrukto materiala e kontreyura di dokumento, ni havas la verbo: destruktar. Do ni darfas rezervar nihiligar a la yurala senco (igar tote ne-valida o sen-valora). Remarkez, ke propre dicite on povas nihiligar nulo materiale, pro ke la materio esas permananta; on povas nur destruktar (quaze des-konstruktar) la material objekti; VI-537.
nikelo (metal.) nickel; nikelizar to nickel-plate (ulo).
nikelino* nickeline; niccolite.
nikotino nicotine.
niktalopa (med.) nyctalopic: part blind by day; niktalopeso nyctalopia: day blindness.
nimbo (meteor.) nimbus: a large rain-cloud of uniform greyness (N.B. not halo; cf. aureolo).
nimfo (myth.) nymph.
nipelo (tech.) nipple. Def.: Interna junto-tubeto kun filetoza extremaji.
«nirvana» (Buddhism) Nirvana.
nitro* (chem.) nitrogen, azote (cf. azoto); nitrato nitrate; nitratacido nitric acid.
nivar (impers.) to snow; niveskarto commence to snow; nivoza, nivatra, nivea snowy; nivo bulo snowball; nivfloko snowflake; nivea barbo snow-white beard.
nivelo level: horizontal surface; (cf. plano, plata); nivelizar to measure the level of, to find the height of (by a surveyor’s level); nivelizilo level instrument which shows the level.
niveolo (bot.) snow-drop (Galanthus nivalis).
nixo, nixulo, nixino (myth.) nix, water sprite, undine.
