no (interj.) no! Ant. yes.

nobela noble (by birth); nobelo, nobelulo, nobelino a noble; nobelaro nobility (collect.) –eso (rank) nobility; nobeligar to ennoble: raise to nobility (ulu). V. exp.: Nobela, nobla La nobeli esas sociala klaso, qua formacesis per la reputeso heredita de la ancestri da la decendanti. Nobleso esas etikal traito. Nobelo tote ne bezonas esar nobla, ed inversa nobla homo ne bezonas esas nobela.
nobla noble (morally); nobleso nobility (of character); nobligar to ennoble: to make noble. V. exp.: vid. nobela. Ant.: abjekta, vulgara, infama.
nocar (tr.) to harm, injure, hurt, wrong, be injurious (ulu, ulo); noceso (state) damage; nociva noxious, nocive, harmful, detrimental. V.exp.: vid. detrimentar.

nocho notch, nick, dent, indentation; nochizar to notch, dent. Def.: V-forma dentizuro (quale en flecho, dento-roto; l’intervalo o lakuno inter du denti di ingranajo, do l’inverso di dento; (kp. III-142). Mikra kavajo produktita per instrumento o frapo.
nociono notion. Def.: Ideo quan on havas pri ulo. Ex. La koncienco direte donas al homo nociono pri la bono e lo mala. Il donos a vu nociono pri ca afero.
nodo knot (in thread, cord, rope, etc.); (nav.) knot: nautical mile: 6080.27 ft., 1852 meters (metres); nodigar to tie a knot in (ulo); nodifar to knot: produce knots; nodo Gordiala Gordian knot.

noktar (impers.) to be night; noktas it is night; nokteskar night is coming on; noktala nocturnal. (ye) noktesko (at) nightfall; nokto night (cf. tenebro,obskuro); noktomezo midnight; noktovaganto, noktero night prowler; noktovazo chamber-pot; noktolampo, noktbujio night-light; noktomarvelo (bot.) marvel of Peru (Mirabilis).
noktiluko (zool.) noctiluca (genus: Noctiluca).
noktuo (orni.) white owl, barn-owl (Noctua); (cf. IV-296).
nokturno (mus.) nocturne.

nomar (tr.) to name: call (ulu) by name, to say the name of (ulu); nomesar to be named, to be called; nomo name; (gram.) noun; nomizar to name: give a name to (ulo); nomizo, nomuro naming; appelation; nomizado nomenclature (cf. nomenklaturo); nome namely (viz.); bapto nomo Christian name; pre nomo first name; ye la nomo di in the name of; ye mea nomo (vice me) in my name; propra nomo own name; proper noun; sen noma nameless. Def.: Dicar, lektar o pensar la nomo; «nom-izar» esas donar nomo (nova); IV-164. Ex.: Ka vu nomas ta persono? La persono nomesas S.X. Lua gepatri nomizis il Jean X. (gram.) Propra, komuna nomo; nomo-substantivo; nom-adjektivo.
nomad(ulo), nomada.nomad(ic).

nombro (cardinal) number, numeral (i.e. numbers used in simple counting: 1, 2, 3, etc. cf. numero); (gram.) number; nombrizar to give numbers to; to count, take census of; nombro prima prime number; nombrala numerical; granda nombra numerous; sen nombra numberless (cf. nekontebla).
nomenklaturo nomenclature.

nominar (tr.) to nominate: to name as a canditate for election or appointment to an office or title; nomino, nomineso (act. condition) nomination, appointment, designation; nominala (of price, value) nominal; nominanto, nominero nominator, presenter; nominato, nominario nominee; nominalismo (philos.) nominalism.
nominativo (gram.) nominative.
nomografio* nomography.

non nine; nono the ninth; nonesma, nonesmo (ordinal) ninth, (rel.) novena (nine days devotion); nonimo (fraction) a ninth part; nonopla ninefold; nonadekyara, nono nonogenarian; nonadek ninety; (cf. du).
nopalo (bot.) nopal, Indian-fig, cochineal-tree (Opuntia coccinellifera).
nordo north; nordala nothern; norde northerly, in the north (with movement: ad –e); nordesto north-east.
norio* noria: a machine for raising water by buckets on an endless chain.

normo norm: authoritative standard or model; norma of or constituting a norm, rule, or principle; normala ordinary, regular, normal: relating to an authoritative standard, as in speaking of health, etc.; (goem.) -ala, normalo normal: perpendicular to a tangent; normigar to establish (ulo) as a norm, to make a standard of (ulo); normizar to furnish with a standard, norm; normaligar to standardize; to seal (weights, measures); pezo normo standard of weights. V. exp.: Regulo esas precepto o preskripto generala, enuncita per vorti. Normo esas kozo konkreta, qua servas quale modelo o tipo a qua on komparas la ceteri por evaluar lia justeso; III-410.
nostalgio nostalgia, homesickness.
nostoko* (bot.) nostoc: a plant of blue-green algæ (genus: Nostoc).

notar (tr.) to note down, set down in writing, make memo of; (cf. remarkar); notizar to annotate, make notes in (a book); (mus.) to write down the notes; (N.B. on notas remarki en libro; on notizas libro per remarki; cf. Talmey’s Text Book, p. 109); noto noting; note, mark, memo, minute (to assist the memory); (mus.) note (written or sounded); (diplom.) note; notiz(ad)o, notizuro annotation, notation (musical, chemical, etc.); inventory; notiziva annotative; notizanto, notero annotator; notlibreto memorandum book (cf. poshkayero); notoreferi reference marks (signs, numbers), etc.).
notario notary (public); koram notario in the presence of a notary.

notico (short) notice, note, or account (instructive or informative as on bottle labels, or in a museum, etc.); notico biografiala biographical sketch. Def.: Nelonga skribajo instruktiva o informiva pri partikulara temo od objektivo; III-204. V. exp.: avizo.
notifikar (tr.) to notify (formally), give notice of (ulo, ad ulu). V. exp.: savigar.
notora manifest, well-known, known generally, notorious (N.B. but not in a bad sense); notoreso notoriety, notoriousness.

nova (of things) new, novel; (of persons) new (in service, office); nov(ul)o a newcomer; novajo a new thing, novelty; nove newly , freshly (cf. recente); nove naskinto a new-born child; novyaro, nova New Year; novigar to innovate (ulo) (intr.: enduktar novajo); noviganto, novero innovator; V. exp.: vid. anciena.

novelo short story, novelette; novelisto short-story writer. V. exp.: Romano esas generale libro kontenanta fingita historio di un o plura personi. Novelo signifikas nur rakonto de kelka pagini, qua havas la naturo di romano, me esas romano tre kurta, tam per l’ampleso kam per la duro (generale on rakontas nur aventuro, epizodo, fakto); IV-291-2.
novembro November.
novic(ul)o novice, probationer, tyro, neophyte, apprentice; novica (fig.) novice: inexperienced, green, raw (of persons); noviceso novitiate, probationship.
nu (interj.) well! now then! come now! well now!

nuanco nuance: a slight shade, gradation, as of tone, colo(u)r, meaning, etc.; nuancoza full of shades, tints, slight gradations or distinctions; nuancizar to shade, variegate, express the nuances; la nuanci inter sinonimi the shades of difference between synonyms.
nubo cloud; (fig.) gloom, darkness, shadow; nubaro (a mass of) clouds; nuboza cloudy, nubilous; nubizar to cloud, cover with clouds.
nuco a walnut; (fig,) nut: any hard shell enclosing a kernel; nuciero (wal)nut tree; nucierligno walnut (wood); nucruptilo nut-cracker.
nuda nude, naked, bare; nudigar to strip, undress, lay bare, denude; nudkapa bare-headed; nudpeda bare-footed; lo nuda (abstract) the nude.
nudli noodles, ribbon vemicelli, spaghetti.
nugato nougat, a kind of almond cake.
nuko nape of the neck; nukumo, nukkovrilo neck-covering, -flap (as to protect against sun or rain); (fig.) muffler. Def.: Nuk-umo esas acesoro o peco di kasqueto; IV-337.
nuklo* (biol.) nucleus.
nukleino* nuclein.

nula no, not any none; nule, nulmaniere nowise, in no way, not at all; nulo nothing; (interj.) no use! no go! not a bit of it! -u no one, nobody; nulajo nullity (cf. nihilo); nulo pluse nothing more; nulkaze in no case; nulloke nowhere; nultempe never; nulaganta, nulema; nulfacanta, nulemo do-nothing, idle (person) (cf. indolenta); nulsavanta ignorant; (cf. nesavo); nulvaloranta of no value, worthless, invalid. Ant.: kelka
numero (ordinal) number (i.e. indicative of order or succession; as 1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.); numerala numerical (order); numerizar to give successive numbers (to houses, journals, etc.).
numeratoro (arith.) numerator.
numismatiko numismatics.
numulario (bot.) moneywort (Lysimachia Nummularia).
numulito (paleon.) nummulite.

nun (adv.) now, at present, at this time; nuna (time) present, actual, current, now occurring (cf. prezenta); nuntempa present day, time; nuntempe at the present time; nuna stando the existing condition, status quo; nuna evento a present, current event; nun kande now when, now that (N.B. not nun ke). Ex.: Me lernas nun la internaciona linguo. Nun kande il venis, ni iros.
nuncio (Pope’s) nuncio.
nupciala (zool.) nuptial.

nur (adv.) only; nura indicates exclusion (of all else) only, sole (cf. sola, unika); ne nur not only; se nur if only, providing that; nur ed unike purely and simply. Ex.: Nur l’amo inspiras il. Il drinkas nur vino. Me donas ol a vu, se nur vu venos. Il nura (od, sola) esas kulpoza.
nutaco* (astron., plant physiol.) nutation.
o(d) (The «d» is omitted before consonants) (conj.) or; o(d) . . o(d) either … or; il devos o submisar o demisar he should either submit or resign (cf. sive).
oaziso oasis.
obcenaobscene.
obediar (tr.) to obey; obediesar to be obeyed; obedi(ad)o obedience, obeying, observance (of a law, command, etc.); obediema (tendency) obedient. Ex.: La soldato obedias sua chefo.
obelisko obelisk.

obeza obese (cf. korpulenta, repleta); obezeso obesity. Def.: Qua havas tro abunta graso, precipue en la ventro: on qualifikas lu vulgare «ventroza». L’obezeso esas maladeso e preske infirmeso; VI-601.
objecionar (tr.) to object: adduce as an objection. Ex.: On objecionis a Galileo ke, se la tero rotacas …
objekto object: anything that comes within the cognizance of the senses (cf. skopo, komplemento); objektala objective (opp. to subjektala); objektalo (opt.) object-glass; objektaleso objectivity.
oblato wafer. Def.: Dina tabuleto ek farinpasto (azimo) uzata por siglar letri.
obleo wafer: a thin pastry.

obligar (tr.) to oblige: put (ulu) under obligation to do or not to do something, to bind, constrain (by duty, hono(u)r, etc.) (cf. devar, koaktar); obligo, obligeso obligation (imposed by conscience, law, etc.); obliganta obligatory (which obliges); obligata (which is) obligatory, incumbent; reciproka obligeso joint liability, obligation; neobligata optional; obligesar ad ulu to be beholden to someone; obligar ulu per juro to bind a person by oath; me obligas me facar to I assume the obligation, the responsibility to do this.
obligaciono (fin.) debenture, bond: a legal obligation (bond) bearing interest; fervoyala obligacioni railway bonds; obligacionierobond-, debenture-holder.

obliqua (also anat., gram.) oblique, aslant, slanting; (fig.) indirect, not straightforward, insincere; obliqua angulo, lineo oblique angle, line; oblique tranchar stofo to cut fabric slantingly, on the bias; ta aleo esas obliqua that lane runs slantingly; (gram.) -a kazooblique case; (fig.) -a laudo indirect praise; obliqua homulo an insincere (not straightforward) man.

obliterar (tr.) to obliterate, blot out (little by little or in a manner to leave traces). V. exp.: Nek efacar, nek nuligar, ma nuligar per signo, qua igas ulo neuzebla (ex. postal marko); IV-394. Ex.: La censuristo obliteris la enskriburo.

obliviar (tr.) to forget (cf. neglijar, omisar); obliviigar to cause (ulu) to forget, to cause (ulo) to be forgotten (da ulu); oblivio forgetting; oblivieso forgetfulness, oblivion; su oblivio self-forgetfulness; obliviema forgetful, oblivious, unmindful; obliviokarcero oubliette: castle dungeon.
oblonga oblong. Def.: Qua esas plu longa kam larja.
obolo (Gr. coin) obol(us); any of several small European coins; mite, groat, farthing; a very small sum; obolo di vidvino widow’s mite.

obsedar (tr.) to beset: to haunt, importune; to obsess, to worry; to possess (by fixed ideas); (cf. persekutar, tedar); la kortani obsedas la princo the courtiers beset the prince; la mento ofte obsedesas da sua propra erori the mind is often beset with its own errors; ca viro obsedas me that man worries me, or, importunes me. V. exp.: Obsedar esas, etimologie, «siejar» persono, t.e. frequentar lu tedante por solicitar lu pri ula kozo, o por vidar lu nediskrete; figurale, to dicesas pri la pensi, imaji, pasioni qui okupas konstante la mento, e quin on ne povas repulsar (la remorso obsedas la kriminanto; teroriganta sonji obsedas lu); III-35.

observar (tr.) to observe: look at, watch (with attention and study); (cf. obediar, remarker); observo observation (of an object); observanta, observema observing, observant; observanto, observero, observisto lookout, observer; observeyo, observposteno place of observation, lookout post; observebla observable. Ex.: Observar naturo, la irado di la astri, la mori di la diferenta nacioni. Astronomiala observado. Mento observema.
observatorio (astron., meteorol.) observatory.
obsidiano (min.) obsidian: volcanic glass.

obskura (lit. and fig.) obscure: without sufficient light to enable one to see objects, gloomy, dim, somber (sombre); not easily understood; little known; (of colo(u)rs) dark; obskurigar to obscure, dim, darken; nokto obskura a dark night; stilo obskura an unclear style; vivar obskura vivo to live an obscure life; obskureso di lingui obscurity of language; la nubi obskurigas la jorno the clouds intercept the daylight; longa frazi obskurigas la senco long sentences obscure the meaning. Ant.: klara.
obskurantismo obscurantism; obskurantisto obscurantist: one who opposes enlightenment.
obsoleta obsolete (words, customs, etc.); obsoleteskar to become obsolete; obsoleteso obsoleteness, desuetude, disuse. Def.: Exter la uzado, la kustumo.
obstaklo (lit. and fig.) obstacle, hindrance, obstruction, impediment, bar, clog: that which opposes; obstaklokuro obstacle-race; (kaval) kuro kun obstakli steeple-chase.

obstinar (intr.) to be obstinate (en, pri) to persist, be firmly bent (on); obstin(ad)o obstinacy, perinacity, stubborness (cf. persistemeso); obstinanta, obstinera, obstinema obstinate, self-willed, opiniated, headstrong, stubborn; obstinemo an obstinate person; il obstinas en taco he keeps obstinately silent; esar obstinanta pri projeto nerealigebla to persist in an impractical project. V. exp.: vid. insistar.
obtenar (tr.) to obtain, procure, get (ulo, de ulu). Ex.: Obtenar favoro de ulu. V. exp.: vid. recevar.
obturar (tr., tech.) to obturate: to stop or close, as an opening.

obtuza obtuse: blunt, dull, (of edges, angles); (geom.) larger than a right angle; (fig.) dull (in sensibility, mentality); obtuzigar to blunt, dull (cf. senpintigar); obtuzangula obtuse angular. Ex.: Hakilo obtuza. Il esas homo mente obtuza. Ant.: akuta.
obuso (artil.) shell; obuskanono howitzer (cf. bombardilo).
oceano acean; (fig.) sea, flood, great quantity (cf. maro); oceanido (myth.) Oceanide, sea-nymph.
oceloto (zool.) ocelot (Felis pardalis).

ociar (intr.) to be idle, be unoccupied; ocio (temporary) idleness, unoccupation; ociado (pemanent, habitual) idleness, leisure; ocioza unoccupied; ociozega, ociema lazy, slothful, indolent; ocianto, ociero idler, person of leisure; ociemo loafer, sluggard. Def.: Esar en stando di senlaboreso. Ociemeso esas la tendenco a ne laborar, a facar nulo; ocioza signifikas la fakto, ne tendenco; IV-287. V. exp.: On povas laborar dum sua libertempi, ma ne dum periodo di ocio (cf. chomar, flanar).

ocidar (tr.) to slay, murder: kill with violence; ocidar su to commit suicide; hom ocido homicide; (cf. rejocido, infantocido, suocido); Def.: Mort-igar violente (intence o ne, krimine o ne); III-697. V. exp.: On ocidas anke bestii, ne nur en bucheyo (ube on buchas li), ma en chaso ed en mult altra okazioni. Ni havas asasinar por la ocido esence krimina; mortigar havas logikale la senco: igar mortar. ex.: ta yuno mortigis sua gepatri pro chagreno; ta acidento mortigis plura personi pro pavoro; III-697; onmasakrasplura personi kruele o senbezone; III-698.
ocidento (literary term) occident (cf. westo).
ocilar (intr.) to oscillate: swing back and forwards (cf. vibrar, fluktuar); ocililo swing (cf. baskulilo).
ocipito (anat.) occiput: back part of head or skull; ocipitala occipital; ocipitala osto, ocipitalo occipital bone.
ocitar (intr., of persons) to yawn (cf. bear).
od see o(d).
odo ode.
odalisko odalisque, odalisk.
«odeon» (ancient) odeum, odeon; (theater in Paris) Odeon.
odiar (tr.) to hate (ulu, ulo); odiesar to be hated (da); odiozeso hatefulness; odiema, odiiganta invidious; odiinda odious; (cf. abominar).
odiseo (pr. and fig.) Odyssey.

odorar (intr.) to have a smell or scent, smell (fragrant, etc.), exhale odo(u)r; (cf. flarar); odoro odor, scent, smell (cf. parfumo, flaro); odoranta, odoroza odoriferous; sen odora, ne odoroza odorless; bonodora fragrant, sweet-smelling; mal odoro bad odor.
ofertorio* (R.C. rel.) offertory.

ofico (function, duty, assigned service) office, post (cf. oficio, employo); oficala functionary relating to office, duty; (cf. oficiala); oficisto a (civil) official (cf. oficiro); oficestro head of (civil) office. Def.: Funciono administrala o direktala, sive en la stato, sive en societo o grand entraprezo; III-697.
oficiar (intr., eccl.) to officiate: perform divine service; oficianta, oficianto officiating (priest or clergyman); oficio office (divine service); oficiala relating to divine service (cf. oficala).
oficiro (milit. nav., of an order) officer (cf. oficisto); sub oficirosubordinate officer, non-commissioned officer.
ofikleido (mus. instr.) ophicleide.
ofito* ophite, greeen porphyry, serpentine.

ofrar (tr.) to offer, proffer, tender (ulo ad ulu), to offer (to do); to place at the service of (ulu); ofrar su to offer, propose (oneself); ofro offering (act), offer, tender, proposal, bid; ofrajo what is offered; ofro (polit. econ) supply: what is offered; Ex.: Ofrar helpo, sua brakio a siorino, sua manuo ad amiko, viktimo en sakrifiko, acompanar ulu. La lego di l’ofro e di la demando determinas la preco di la vari sur ula merkato. V. exp.: Il propozis a me irar kun il en la teatro, ma il ne ofris a me plaso. On povas ofrar la vari sen prizentar li: en la komercal borso, on ne prizentas la vari ipsa, same kam en la financal borso en ne prizentas la valori: tamen on ofras li; II-79, 167.

ofte oft, often, oftentimes; ofta frequent; maxim ofte most often, very often; ne ofte rarely, seldom. Ex.: Ofte on mustas facar ulo quon on ne deziras facar. V. exp.: Ofta ne esas sinonima a frequa. Ofta dicesas pri ulo quo eventas «ofte», t.e. multa foyi en ula intervalo. Frequa esas utila en tekniko: ex. on bezonas parolar pri flui (elektrala) di granda frequeso: on ne povas dicar: di granda ofteso to semblus signifikar, ke on uzas li ofte; IV-237. Ant.: rara.
oftalmio ophthalmia.
oftalmologio* ophthalmology.
oftalmoskopo* ophthalmoscope.
ogivo (arch.) ogive.
oglar (tr.) to ogle: view with side glances; to cast glances at slyly; oglachar to leer at (ulu).
ogr(ul)o ogre.

ok eight; okesma (ordinal) eighth; okopla, okoplo eight-fold, octuple; okimo one-eighth; okadek eighty, fourscore; okadekyara, oko octogenarian; okima negro octoroon: person one-eighth black; (cf. du).
okarino (mus. instr.) ocarina.
okaziono occasion, opportunity; okazione occasionally, at times; okazione di apropos (of); (cf. kauzo). Ex.: Me kaptis la okaziono por parolar ad il. Kande okaziono prizentos su, ni iros.
okro ochre; reda okro red ochre.
oktaedro* (geom.) octahedron.
oktanto octant: eighth of a circle; (astron. instr.) octant.
oktavo (mus., ch. festival, verse) octave.
oktiliono* (English notation) octillion (1,000,000 8 ).
oktobro October.
oktogono* (geom.) octagon.
oktopodo* octopod (having eight legs); order Octopoda; (cf. polpo).

okulo eye; okuleto small eye; (tech.) eyelet hole; okulala ocular; okulalo eye-piece, eye-glass; okulisto oculist; okulagar (tr.) to eye (ulu, ulo); okulo nuda naked eye; okulo po okulo eye for eye; okulklapo, okulshirmilo eye-shade; (for horses) blinker; okuloskrubo a staple, eyebolt: screw with ringed head.
okulta occult. V. exp.: vid. arkana.
okultaco (astron.) occultation; okultacar (tr.) to occult.

okupar (tr.) to occupy (a place, time); okupar su to occupy oneself, employ oneself, be busy (pri); okupesar to be occupied (da); okupeso occupancy (fact); okup(ad)ooccupying;okupantajo, okupivo (that which occupies) business, work, occupation; okupanto, okupero occupant; okupata occupied, busy. Ex.: La lito okupas la tota spaco. La soldati okupis la urbo. La diskutado okupis la tempo. Ca laboro okupis dek yari di lua vivo. Il okupis su en (od, pri) sua gardeno. Esar sen okupeso. La okupo di la urbo da la trupi. La okup-antajo, -ivo di soldati, di komercisto.

ol (abbr. for olu; acus. olun) (neuter pronoun referring to a definite object; cf. lo, lu) it; oli they (cf. li); olua its; olia their (cf. lia). Ex.: Ol esas tre bela. La afero semblas bona, ma forsan ol ne esas tala. La kavalo esas tro fatigita; ol(u) ne povus tirar la veturo, La viri e la bestii ne konkordas inter su, nam ili (la viri) tiris ad-dextre, dum ke oli (la bestii) tiris adsinistre.

olda (of living beings) old, of advanced age; oldo, oldulo, oldino old person; oldeso oldness; oldaro (collect.) aged persons; oldeskar to grow old; (plu-) -igar to age, make look old. Def.: Di evo avanc-inta. V. exp.: vid. anciena. Ant.: yuna.

oleo oil; oleoza, oleatra oleaginous; oleizar to oil (ulo); oleifar to produce oil, give out oil; oleuyo oil-holder, oilcan; cruet; olelampo Argand lamp: common oil lamp for illumination; olefarbo oil paint; olei santa (eccl.) holy oils; brul oleo lamp-oil, kerosene; ricin oleo castor oil; oliv oleo olive-oil.
olfaktar* (tr.) to perceiveby sense of smell; olfakto olfaction. -ala organo olfactory organ.
olibano olibanum: frankincense.
oligarko* oligarch.
oligarkio oligarchy.
oligoceno (geol.) oligocene.
olim formerly, in former times, once upon a time; olima former; olima tempo in days of old. Ex.: Olim esis kustumo. La homi di olima tempo. Olim ula princo regnis. Olima kustumo.
Olimpo* Olympus; Olimpano a dweller in Olympus.
olimpiado Olympiad: a period of four years.
olivo (fruit) olive; oliviero olive tree.
omento* (anat.) omentum.
omisar* (tr.) to omit, leave out or undone, pass over; omiso, omisajo omission (cf. neglijar). Ex.: Omisar formalajo. Ne omisez facar to. Il omisis fakto importanta.
omleto omelet.

omna (collective sense) all, every; omni all, everybody (collect.) -o everything; omnu every one; omna tri, omna quar all three, all four; il havas du filiuli, qui omna esas soldati he has two sons who are (both) soldiers; de omna loki from every place; omnadie, omna daily, every day; omnofacanto factotum; omnakaze in any case, in any event; omnafoye every time; omnaloke every place; omnomanjanta omnivorous (cf. omnivora); omnamonata, omne every month, monthly; omnamaniere in every way; omnopovo omnipotence; omnopovanta omnipotent, all powerful; omnosavoomniscience; omnosavanta omniscient; omnasemena, omne weekly, every week. -osufranto (fig.) drudge; omnasorta, omnspeca every kind of; omnotushero (fig.) meddler, busy-body; omnube wherever. V. exp.: vid. singla.
omnibuso (vehicle) omnibus.
omnivoro ominvorous.

on one (indefinite pronoun): people, men, we, they (when used vaguely for society), for people in general; on dicas people say, they say; on devas amar sua gepatri we should love our parents; on ne povas manjar sua kuko e konservar ol you cannot eat your cake and have it. (Note: Ni translates «we» only when a limited number of persons is thought of with whom the speaker or writer is directly associated: ni qui kredas ke I.L. esas posibla).
onagro* (zool.) onager: a wild ass (Equus Onager); (hist.) onager: a stone-throwing machine.
omaniar* (intr.) to masturbate; omani(ad)o masturbation, onanism.

ondo (lit. and fig.) (small) wave, swell, surge (of water); undulation; ondego billow, breaker; ondifar to rise in billow form or produce waves; to undulate, wave; ondigar, ondizar to cause waves on; to cover with waves; ondifo, ondaro undulation, waves; ondoza, ondatra, ondifanta, ondizita wavy, wavelike, undulating; ondagitata rough; ondagiteso billowy. Ex.: Ondi di maro, di soni, di tero (sismala). La maro ondifas. La vento ond-igas, -izas la maro. Ondoza surfaco.
onixo (min.) onyx.
onkl(ul)o uncle; onklinoaunt; onklala avuncular; preonklulo great-uncle.
onomatopeo (gram.) onomatopoeia.
ontogenezo* (biol.) ontogenesis.
ontologio (philos.) ontology.
onyono (plant and edible bulb) onion; onyoneyo onion-bed; onyonshelo onion-skin, -peel.
oolito (geol.) oolite.
opaka opaque. Def.: Qua ne esas diafana, ne permeebla per lumo. Ant.: diafana, translucida.
opalo (min.) opal; opalvitro (fig.) opal (or, iridescent) glass.
opalecar* (intr.) to opalesce.
opero opera; opereto operetta; operoteatro opera house.

operacar (tr., surg., mil., math., finan.) to operate (upon); operacato, operacito person operated upon; operacar malado, tumoro to operate upon a sick person, a tumor. Ex.: Subisar operaco. Financalo operaco. Operaco en sustraciono. Militala operaco.
operkulo (bot., anat., zool.) operculum (cover, lid).
opiato (med.) opiate.
opinionar (tr.) to opine, express one’s opinion, be of the opinion. Def.: Expresar judiko pri temo. Ex.: Me favore opinionas pri la projeto. Publika opiniono.
opiumo opium; opiumoza containing opium.
opodeldoko* (med.) opodeldoc.

oportar, oportas (intr., impersonal) it is required, it is necessary (ke); (cf. suffix: oportend); oportas levar ni fru morge it is necessary to get up early to-morrow. V. exp.: Kande ica signifiko havas subjekto, on uzas mustar: oportas ke vu departez: vu mustas departar.

oportuna (of things) opportune, seasonable, timely, convenient (cf. favoroza); oportuneso opportuneness (cf. okaziono); oportunismo (politics) opportunism; oportunisto opportunist; (N.B. «opportunity» is translated by okaziono or oportunajo); Ex.: Okaziono oportuna. Oportuneso di la sokurso.

opozar (tr.) to oppose (ulu ad ulo, ulu, ad ulu), to put in opposition to, place (ulo) opposite; opoz(ad)o opposition (resistance); opozeso opposition (contrast, state of); opozanto, opozero opponent; opozata, opozita opposed, opposite (ad); opozantaro the opposition; opozato the opposite; opozar spegulo a la fenestro to set a glass opposite a window; opozar digo a la torento to oppose a dike (dyke) to a torrent; opozar du motivi to put two motives in contrast; la domo opozata the house opposite. (N.B. the basic idea of this word implies putting in contrast, opposing an obstacle, rather than active opposition, therefore, «to oppose»: act in opposition, is translated ordinarily by kombatar, rezistar).

opresar (tr., phys., mental, social) to oppress: to lie heavy on; deject, treat with hardship; (cf. charjegar, presegar); Def.: Presar forte (fizike o etikale) kontre ulu. V. exp.: On esas fizike opresata, kande on respiras kun peno; on esas etikale opresata, kande on angoras pro desquieteso, en expekto di trista evento od informo. La richuli opresas la povruli. La konquestiti povas esar opresata da la konquestanti, la laboristi da la patroni, e.c. III-223.
optativo (gram.) optative.
optiko (science of) optics; optikisto optician: one skilled in optics (cf. okulisto).
optimismo optimism; optimisto, optimista optimist(ic).

or (conj.) now, but (in argument). V. exp.: Or expresas ne nur intersequo di du propozicioni, ma induktas nova argumento, plusa premiso, expliko, motivo. Ex.: Or, vua argumento semblas bona, ma ... Omno qua foligas esas veneno; or l’alkoholo foligas; do ... Kande la premiso (motivo) sequas la konkluzo, or vicesas da nam; ex.: L’alkoholo esas venono, nam ol foligas; kp. nam; VI-141-2; Talmey’s Text Book, p. 113.

oro gold; ora (of gold thread, watch, etc.); orea golden (of hair, etc.); oroza full of, rich in gold, auriferous; ormineyo gold mine; orizar to gild, plate (ulo) with gold; orfolio, orpelikulo gold leaf; orizitaarjento silver-gilt.
oraklo oracle; oraklatra oracular (tone, etc.); oraklifar to declare, utter an oracle.
orangutano (zool.) orang-outang (Pithecus satyrus).
oranjo orange; oranjiero orange tree; oranjiereyo orange grove: oranjea orange colo(u)red; oranjodrinkajo orangeade.
oratoro orator (cf. diskursisto, parolisto.
oratorio (mus.) oratorio.
orbito (astron.) orbit; (anat.) eye-socket.
ordi* (la) (eccl.) holy-orders; izo conferring of holy-orders.
ordeno (eccl. and knighthood) order; ordenizar to knight; ordeninsigno insignia, badge (of knighthood).
ordinacar* (tr., eccl.) to ordain (a priest, clergyman); (cf. ordizar).
ordinara ordinary, common, usual; ordinare commonly, ordinarily. Ex.: Vanitato esas kulpo tre ordinara. Ordinara manjajo, homo. Ant.: extraordinara.
ordinato (geom.) ordinate.
ordonanco (milit.) orderly; ordonancoficiro ordinance officer. Def.: Soldato qua exekutas o transmisas la komandi di oficiro; la ordinanc-oficiro ludas simila rolo apud supera oficiro; III-266.
oreado* (myth.) oread, mountain nymph.

orelo ear, auricle; (fig.) hearing; orelala auricular; orelkovrilo, orelumo ear-covering, ear-flap; orelringo ear-ring; orelfingro little finger; oreloza; grandorela big-eared; (horses) lop-eared; orelkuracisto aurist; orelzumado buzzing, ringing in the ears; askoltar per omna oreli (fig.) to be all ears, to listen intently; havar orelo justa (od, delikata): to have a good (or, delicate) ear (as for music); levar (od, tensar) la oreli to prick up the ears.
oreliono (med.) mumps; an infectious inflammation of various glands (cf. parotidito).
«oremus»oremus, orison, prayer (Let us pray).
orfana; o, ulo, ino orphan; ala relating to orphans; erio orphanage, orphan asylum.

organo organ (part of an organized body); (fig.) instrument, means; (cf. orgeno); organala organic: relative to organs or organized means; (cf. organika); organizar to organize: furnish with organs; (cf. aranjar, institucar); organizo, organizeso, organizuro organization (cf. ordino, konstituciono, organismo); organizanto organizer. Ex.: L’okulo esas l’organo di vidado. Ca jurnalo esas l’organo di demokratio; (fig.) La judiciisto esas la organo di la lego. Organizar ministerio. Organizuro di la homala korpo. Muzikala organizuro.
organdio (fabric) organdy. Def.: Speco di muslino; IV-448.
organicismo* (med.) organicism.
organika (chem.) organic (substances, chemistry, etc.; cf. organala).
organismo (lit. and fig.) organism. Def.: (lit.) Ensemblo di la organi (la organaro) qui konstitucas ento vivanta. Ex.: Homala organismo. (fig.) Politikala organismo.
organzino organzine: a double-thrown silk used in weaving.
orgeno (mus.) organ; orgen(ple)isto organist; turn orgeno barrel-, hand-organ.
orgio orgy.

oriento Orient, the east; orientala oriental; orientano an oriental; orientalisto orientalist; orientizar (pr. and fig.) to orient: place or set toward the east; (fig.) to give the correct aspect, the right direction to; (nav.) to trim (sails); orientizar to adjust one’s bearings toward the east; (fig.) to ascertain one’s position, find out what one is about; orientizar ulu en lua studiado to guide, set someone in the right direction in his studies; esas nefacila orientizar su en la mezo di revoluciono it is difficult to get one’s bearings, find out one’s true position, in the midst of revolution (cf. esto).
orifico orifice (cf. aperturo, boko, truo).
oriflamo oriflamme: ancient French banner.
origano (bot.) origan: a majoram (genus: Origanum).

origino origin (cf. fonto); originala original: relating to origin; not copied; (cf. stranja); originaleso originality; originalajo (of things) the original, first copy; original(ul)o eccentric person, odd fellow; origine, originale originally, primitively; in the beginning, by origin. Ex.: Origino di vorti, di la mondo. Originala edituro, penso, pikturo. La pikturo montras originaleso. Kopiuro konforma a la originalajo.
orikalko (met.) orichalk. Def.: Anciena nomo di latuno.
oriolo (orni.) oriole (European: Oriolus galbula: golden oriole).
oripelo tinsel; Dutch gold. Def.: Dina, oratra folieto, quan on uzas por orizar diversa objekti; VI-142. V. exp.: Orpelikulo (E. gold leaf) esas vera oro; oripelo imitas l’oro; (kp. flitro); VI-142.
orjato orgeat: an almond syrup.
orkestro orchestra: a part in theater (theatre) nearest the stage; a company of instrumental performers.
orkideo (bot.) orchid
orlar (tr., needle-work) to hem: turn down and sew the edge of (a garment, fabric); orluro hem; (arch., herald.) orlet, orle; (cf. rifaldar, orluro).

ornar (tr.) to adorn, embellish, bedeck (ulo, ulu, per ulo); (cf. dekorar, plubeligar); orno adorning; ornivo adornment, ornament (cf. ornamento); orniva decorative, ornamental. Ex.: La domi esas neta, komoda, ma li ne esas ornita. Ornar parko per statui. (fig.) Ca viri esas ornivi di nia yarcento.
ornamento ornament, embellishment; (mus.) grace-note; (cf. ornivo); ornamentala ornamental; ornamentizar to ornament, decorate (cf. ornar, dekorar); ornamento ek diamanti diamond ornament.
ornitologio ornithology.
ornitoptero ornithopter: a flying machine propelled by flapping wings.
orografio orography: mountain physiography.
orpimento orpiment: arsenic trisulphide.
orselo (bot.) archil, orchil, orseille.
orta right (angle); (cf. rekta); orto a right angle; orte at a right angle; ortangula orthogonal, rectangular.
ortocentro* (geom.) orthocenter.
ortodoxa (rel. and fig.) orthodox; ortodoxeso orthodoxy; ortodox(ul)o orthodox person. Ant.: heterodoxa.
ortogenezo* (biol.) orthogenesis.
ortografio orthography (cf. espelado); kulpo ortografiala mistake in spelling.
ortografika* (geom.) orthographic.
ortokroma* (photog.) orthocromatic.
ortolano (orni.) ortolan (Emberiza hortulana).
ortopedio (surg.) orthopedics. Def.: L’arto qua korektigas o preventas deformaji di la korpo.
ortoptero orthopterous insect.
orveto orvet: blind-worm, slow-worm (Anguis fragilis).
orvietano orvietan: a pretended antidote or counter-poison.
osifrago (orni.) ossifrage, osprey, sea-eagle. (Falco ossifragus).
oskular* (tr., intr., geom.) to osculate.
osmio* (chem.) osmium.
osmoso (physics) osmosis, osmose.

osto bone; osteto small bone, ossicle; ostala, ostoza osseous, bony; (fig.) large-boned; ostaro bony frame-work (cf. skeleto); ostigar to ossify; osteskar to become ossified; ostifado, ostesko ossification; ostokarbono bone-black; ludar per osteti to play at knuckle-bones.
ostensorio (R.C. rel.) ostensorium, monstrance.
ostentar (tr., intr.) to do a thing out of ostentation, show off, make a show (pri), parade (ulo); (fig.) to swagger; ostentanta, ostentoza, ostentema ostentatious. V. exp.: vid. fanfaronar.
osteologio osteology.
osteomo* (med.) osteoma.
ostito* (med.) ostitis.
ostro oyster; ostrostrato, ostreyo oyster-bed; ostrkultiv(ad)o oyster culture.
ostracismo ostracism: banishment (cf. exilar).
ostrogoto* Ostrogoth.
otalgio* (med.) otalgia: ear-ache.
otario otary: eared-seal. Def.: Speco di mar-hundo kun oreli; V-341. (Otariidae).
otito* (med.) otitis; otitointerna inflammation of the middle-ear.
otolito* (anat., zool.) otolith, ear-stone.
otomano ottoman. Def.: Speco di divano; IV-395.

otuso (vulgara) common owl, long-eared owl (Otus); otuso penachetoza short-eared owl (Otus brachyotus, Asio accipitrinus, Strix brachyotus, Brachotus palustris). Def.: Noktala ucelo di qua la kapo esas ornita per penacheti quaze «oreleti»; IV-296.

ovo egg; ovi eggs; (of fish) roe; ovoshelo egg-shell; ovuyo egg-cup, -holder; ovajo an egg preparation; ovifar to lay eggs; ovo (mole o harde o mimole) koquita boiled egg; ovo sur plado fried egg; ovo mixita scrambled egg; ovo dispersita poached egg; ovvendisto egg-seller; ovoplanto egg-plant (Solanum ovigerum) (cf. berenjeno).
ovacionar (tr.) to give an ovation to, to receive in triumph (ulu); ovaciono ovation.
ovala, ovalo oval.
ovario (anat., bot.) ovary.
ovipara, oviparo oviparous (animal).
ovulo (physiol., bot.) ovule; ovulif(ad)o ovulation.
oxo* oxygen (the scientific word; cf. oxigeno); oxizar to oxygenate.
oxalo (bot.) sorrel (genus: Rumex); oxalatacido o. acid; oxalato oxalate o. salt.
oxaliko (chem.) oxalic.
oxido (chem.) oxide; oxidigar to oxidate: convert into an oxide.
oxigeno oxygen; oxigenizar oxygenize. V. exp.: Oxigeno esas la ordinara vorto; oxo nur la ciencala vorto, partikulare utila en kemiala terminaro.
oxikoko (berry) cranberry; oxikokiero cranberry bush (genus: Oxucoccus).
oziero (bot.) osier (Salix viminalis); oziera korbo wicker basket.

pacar (intr.) to be at (or, in) peace; pacigar to pacify, appease; paceskar to make peace (kun); pacifar to make for peace; paco peace; pacala relating to peace; pacema pacific: who likes peace; pacoza peaceful: which is at peace; pacifanta, paciganta pacifying; pacigo pacification, peace-making, appeasement; pacifismo pacifism; pacifista, paco pacifist.
pachulio (perfume) patchouli.

pacienta patient; pacienteso patience, calm endurance or waiting, forbearance; pacientesar to be patient, have patience, bide one’s time; ludo di pacienteso (game) patience. Ex.: Il esas pacienta en doloro. Vartar paciente. La patrulo pacientesis pri sua filio.
Pacifiko Pacific Ocean.

pado pad, padding; listing (put around doors and windows to keep out cold); padizar to pad, stuff (window, etc.); padochapelo porter’s pad (for burdens); padded cap (worn by children); stulo pado chair-pad. Def.: Kusen(et)o (generale ronde e kun truo en mezo); polsteraji quin on pozas cirkum la pordi e fenestri por kalfatar l’aperturi.
padelo frying-pan, skillet: metal vessel with long handle used for frying.
«padishah» (title) padishah.
padloko padlock; padlokizar to padlock, fasten with a padlock.

pafar (tr., intr.) to shoot (with firearms); pafo a shot (fired); pafado firing, volley; pafilo a fire-arm; pafajo a charge, shot (for firing); paflineo line of fire; pafaperturo loop-hole; skoppafado target-firing.

pagar (tr., lit. and fig.) to pay (ulu, ulo), to pay for (ulo); pag(ad)o (act) pay, payment; pagenda payable: which must be paid; paganto, pagero one who pays; pagisto paymaster; pagajo payment: sum paid; pagodio pay day; pagopor dio a day’s pay; pagodato, paglimito maturity (of a debt). Ex.: Pagar la domaji, la kusti, la perdo. Pagar la laboristi. (fig.) Pagar sua krimino per la vivo.
pagana: o, ulo, ino pagan, heathen; eso, ismo paganism.
pagayo paddle (as for canoe); pagayagar (tr., intr.) to paddle.
pagino page (of a book); paginigar (tr., print.) to make up into pages, to folio; numerizar la pagini to number the pages (di); paginonumero number of page.
pagodo pagoda.
pajo page (boy); (at cards) knave, jack.

pako bundle, package, parcel; paketo packet: small bundle; pakego large bundle, bale; pakigar to bundle up, make (ulo) into a parcel; pakigo, pakuro packing; pakiganto, pakisto packer; paketoposto parcel post.
paketboto packet-boat, mail-packet, liner.
pakidermo (zool.) pachyderm.
pakotilio (com., nav.) (seaman’s) venture. Def.: Diversa vari (mikra) quin la maristi daras embarkar sen pagar freto; III-141.
pala pallid, pale; palega ghastly, wan, sallow; paleso paleness, pallor, wanness; paligar to cause to turn pale; paleskar to turn, grow, become pale, to blanch.
palaco palace.
palado* (chem.) palladium.
paladio (statue and fig.) palladium.
paladino paladin; (fig.) knight-errant.
palankino palanquin.
palato (anat.) palate; palatala (also gram.) palatal; palatalo (also gram.) palatal (-bone); palatvelo velum: soft-palate.
palaten(ul)o a (count) palatine.
palatino fur-tippet (for neck and shoulders).
paleografio paleography; paleografiisto paleographer. Def.: Arto dechifrar la anciena skriburi.
paleontologio paleontology; paleontologiisto paleontologist.
paleozoologio* paleozoology.
palestro (antiq.) palestra.
paleto* paddle-board (of a paddle-wheel); blade (of an oar).
palio straw (fig.) chaff; paliea straw-colo(u)red; paliofasko truss of straw; palitapiso straw matting; paliomatraco straw mattress; paliamaso heap of straw; paliizar to cover with straw.

paliatar (tr. med. and gen.) to palliate; mitigate, alleviate, (a disease); to cloak, extenuate (a fault); paliativa, paliativo palliative. Def.: Alejar maladeso o malajo, sen remediar ol komplete; III-331; Kalmigar provizore. Ex.: Laudano paliatas kelka dolori. Paliatar eroro.
palimpsesta, palimpsesto palimpsest. (manuscript).
palinodio palinode. Def.: Anciena verso en qua la poeto retraktis sua olima opinioni.

paliso stake, pale, picket (as of a fence); palisego pile, large post; palisrango row of stakes, paling (cf. palisado); palisizar to cover with stakes; to stake out, make with stakes. Def.: Longa peco ek ligno (ofte) akutigita ye un extremajo.

palisado palisade, stockade (paling); (cf. palisaro); palisadeto picket (as of a fence) (cf. paliso); palisadcelulo (biol.) p. cell. Def.: Obstaklo (precipue en militarto) ek serio di pintigita palisi o fosti. Anke uzata por la senco biologiala; II-294.
palisandro Palisander: rosewood.
paliumo (ancient and eccl.) pallium.
palmo (bot.) palm(-branch); (anat.) palm (of hand); palmiero palm tree; palmeto (arch.) palmette: carved palm-leaf ornament; palmosundio Palm Sunday.
palmata (zool.) palmate: web-footed.
palmipeda, palmipedo palmiped. Def.: Speci di uceli quale anadi, cigni, pinguini, qui havas pedi palmata.

palpar (tr.) to feel (about); palp(ad)o feeling (by touch); (med.) palpation ( a method of exploration by touch and pressure); palpebla palpable, tangible; (fig.) plain, obvious; palpilo palp(us), feeler, tentacle; palpar su to feel oneself. Def.: Tushar per la fingri o per altro por explorar. Ex.: Palpar la pulsado (di l’arterii) di ulu.
palpebro eyelid; palpebragar (intr.) to wink, blink.
palpitar (intr.) to palpitate, throb; (fig.) to tremble, flutter. Ex.: Kande la kordio palpitas, on ne esas mortinta. Palpitar pro pavoro.
paltoto paletot: a loose coat or jacket worn by both sexes, an overcoat (cf. surtuto).
palumbo (orni.) wood-pigeon, ring-dove (of the Pyranees) (Palumbus).
pamfleto pamphlet (N.B. this refers only to a pamphlet on a satirical or strongly controversial subject; cf. broshuro).
pampro vine-branch (with foliage and fruit). (arch.) pampre.

pano bread (leavened; cf. azimo); loaf (of b.; du pani two loaves of bread); pano nefresha stale b.; panopeco piece of b.; panigar, panifar (tr., intr.) to make, to bake b.; paniferio bakery; panopeceto small piece of bread, b.crumb (cf. krumo); paneyo pantry (bread place); panloncho slice of b.
panaceo panacea, universal remedy.
panariso (med.) panaris: whitlow, felon.
pancho paunch (of animals); (fig.) belly, paunch (of persons). Def.: La unesma e maxim granda stomako di rumineri.
panduro pandour; (fig.) marauder, brutal man. Def.: Speco di Hungariana soldati; IV-269.

panear (intr., nav.) to lie to, be hove to; (fig. esp. automobiling) to be in a state of breakdown or halt (occasioned by accident, misfunction, trouble). V. exp.: Panear: esas en paneo. Paneo ne esas simpla halto, nek avario; ol esas halto koaktata pro avario o pertubo, misfunciono; ol esas verto teknikala di navigado, qua divenis vulgara ed internaciona per l’automobilismo; IV-578.
panegiro panegyric, encomium, eulogy (cf. laudodiskurso).

panelo (arch.) panel, wainscot; (gen.) a flat section of considerable size of a garment, wall or other surface; panelaro waniscotting, panelling (collect.); panelizar to panel, wainscot; panelspegulo pier glass.
pangenezo* pangenesis.
pangolino (zool.) pangolin, scaly anteater, (genus: Manis).
panio waist-cloth, -clout, loin-cloth (of savages or negroes).
panika, paniko panic, sudden fright. Ex.: Panika teroro.
paniklo (anat.) panniculus.
panikulo (bot.) panicle.
pankraco (antiq.) pancratium (an athletic contest).
pankreato (anat.) pancreas; (butch.) sweet-bread; pankreatala pancreatic.
pankreatito* (med.) pancreatitis. Def.: Inflamuro di la pankreati.
panmixio* (biol.) panmixia.
panoramo (lit. anf fig.) panorama.
pansar (tr.) to dress (wounds, sores); pansilo dressing (bandage, etc.).
palmata (zool.) palmate: web-footed.
palmipeda, palmipedo palmiped. Def.: Speci di uceli quale anadi, cigni, pinguini, qui havas pedi palmata.

palpar (tr.) to feel (about); palp(ad)o feeling (by touch); (med.) palpation ( a method of exploration by touch and pressure); palpebla palpable, tangible; (fig.) plain, obvious; palpilo palp(us), feeler, tentacle; palpar su to feel oneself. Def.: Tushar per la fingri o per altro por explorar. Ex.: Palpar la pulsado (di l’arterii) di ulu.
palpebro eyelid; palpebragar (intr.) to wink, blink.
palpitar (intr.) to palpitate, throb; (fig.) to tremble, flutter. Ex.: Kande la kordio palpitas, on ne esas mortinta. Palpitar pro pavoro.
paltoto paletot: a loose coat or jacket worn by both sexes, an overcoat (cf. surtuto).
palumbo (orni.) wood-pigeon, ring-dove (of the Pyranees) (Palumbus).
pamfleto pamphlet (N.B. this refers only to a pamphlet on a satirical or strongly controversial subject; cf. broshuro).
pampro vine–branch (with foliage and fruit). (arch.) pampre.

pano bread (leavened; cf. azimo); loaf (of b.; du pani two loaves of bread); pano nefresha stale b.; panopeco piece of b.; panigar, panifar (tr., intr.) to make, to bake b.; paniferio bakery; panopeceto small piece of bread, b.crumb (cf. krumo); paneyo pantry (bread place); panloncho slice of b.
panaceo panacea, universal remedy.
panariso (med.) panaris: whitlow, felon.
pancho paunch (of animals); (fig.) belly, paunch (of persons). Def.: La unesma e maxim granda stomako di rumineri.
panduro pandour; (fig.) marauder, brutal man. Def.: Speco di Hungariana soldati; IV-269.

panear (intr., nav.) to lie to, be hove to; (fig. esp. automobiling) to be in a state of breakdown or halt (occasioned by accident, misfunction, trouble). V. exp.: Panear: esas en paneo. Paneo ne esas simpla halto, nek avario; ol esas halto koaktata pro avario o pertubo, misfunciono; ol esas verto teknikala di navigado, qua divenis vulgara ed internaciona per l’automobilismo; IV-578.
panegiro panegyric, encomium, eulogy (cf. laudodiskurso).

panelo (arch.) panel, wainscot; (gen.) a flat section of considerable size of a garment, wall or other surface; panelaro waniscotting, panelling (collect.); panelizar to panel, wainscot; panelspegulo pier glass.
pangenezo* pangenesis.
pangolino (zool.) pangolin, scaly anteater, (genus: Manis).
panio waist-cloth, -clout, loin-cloth (of savages or negroes).
panika, paniko panic, sudden fright. Ex.: Panika teroro.
paniklo (anat.) panniculus.
panikulo (bot.) panicle.
pankraco (antiq.) pancratium (an athletic contest).
pankreato (anat.) pancreas; (butch.) sweet-bread; pankreatala pancreatic.
pankreatito* (med.) pancreatitis. Def.: Inflamuro di la pankreati.
panmixio* (biol.) panmixia.
panoramo (lit. anf fig.) panorama.
pansar (tr.) to dress (wounds, sores); pansilo dressing (bandage, etc.).
panseo (bot., flower, plant) pansy (Viola tricolor).
pantalono (long) trousers, a pair of pantaloons (cf. bracho); pantalonfenduro t. flap.
panteismo pantheism.
panteisto, panteista pantheist(ic).
pantero (zool.) panther (Felis pardus).
pantoflo slipper (for foot).
pantografo (instr.) pantograph.
pantometro* (instr.) pantometer.
pantomimo pantomime, dumb-show. Def.: La pleado di aktoro qua ne parolas e konseque expresas «omno» (panto) per gesti parte konvencionala; VII-156.
papo pope; papala papal; papeso (dignity, office) papacy; papismo papism, popery; papisto, papista papist; papigebla eligible to be pope.
papagayo (orni.) parrot.
papavero (bot.) poppy (genus: Papaver); papavereto red (or, corn-) poppy (Papaver Rhoeas.).
papayo (fruit) papaya, papaw; papayiero papaya-tree (Carica Papaya).

papero paper; (fig.) paper document, writing); papera made of p.; paperachi old paper(s), waste p.; absorbiva papero blotting-p.; paperi aferala business papers; paperfabrikeyo p. mill; paperfolio sheet of p.; paperobloko block of p.; papervendisto stationer; paperifisto p. manufacturer; paperklovo thumb-tack (for fastening papers), paper-fastener; paperkorbo basket for p.; paperkorno p. cone; paperkultelo p.-knife;-presilo p.-weight; paperpasto papier-mache; papero striizita, paperlineizita ruled p.;papero statala a state paper; paperuyo p. holder, portfolio; senskriba papero blank p.
papilo (anat., bot.) papilla.
papiliono (ent.) butterfly; papilionatra papilionaceous.
papiro papyrus; (bot.) paper-rush. Def.: Egiptiana arbusto sur la kortico di qua skribis la antiqua, e ta kortico ipsa; III-141.
paplo pap (for infants); pulp (fopr making paper); paplatra pulplike, pulpy.
papriko Cayenne pepper (Capsicum). N.B. «paprika», the mildly pungent condiment might be translated by dolca pimento, dolca papriko.

papulo papule, (solid) pimple (cf. veruko). V. exp.: Papulo esas normala saliajeto di la pelo o di la mukozi (sur la fingri, sur la lango, e.c.). Pustulo esas tumoreto pusifanta (de qua venas lua nomo) en eruptiva morbi (variolo, skarlatino, e.c.); II-646.

para (arith.) even, equal; of equal footing, of a common level; pareso parity; (fin.) par; paro a pair, a couple (of animals, or objects of like nature), brace; parigar to put in two’s, pair, couple, match (by two’s); ye pareso at par, on a par, on an equality; super para, pareso above par; tri para de perdriki three brace of partridges.
parabolo (bibl. etc.) parable; (geom.) parabola.
paraboloido* (geom.) paraboloid.
paracintilo a protection from sparks; fire-screen.
paradar (intr.) to parade (as troops, or like troops); Ex.: Trupi paradas tra la stradi. Parado di cirko. Parado-placo, -agro (E. paradeground).
paradigmo (gram.) paradigm.
paradizo (lit. and fig.) paradise; paradizucelo bird of paradise. Ex.: La paradizo Mohamedala. (fig.) Ca loko esis terala paradizo.

paradoxo paradox; paradoxa, paradoxala, paradoxatra paradoxical (statement, opinion, etc.); paradoxem(ul)o person given to paradox. Def.: Aserto o propoziciono kontre vulgara o komuna opiniono. Ex.: La movado dila tero esis longa-tempe paradoxo.
parafoscrawled initials. paraph: flourish after a signature; parafizar to put one’s initials to (ulo) with an added flourish; parafacho
parafairo screen or protection from fire; fire-guard, fire-screen.
parafalo parachute.
parafango mud-guard.
parafino (chem.) paraffin(e).

parafrazar (tr.) to paraphrase: freely translate, amplify (a text). V. exp.: Perifrazo esas frazo o frazeto uzata por expresar nedirete to quon on povus expresar per un simpla vorto. Ex.: «la flamifanta globo», vice «la suno». Parafrazo esas quaza traduko di frazo o texto en la sama linguo, por klarigar o developar olu. Ex.: La predikero citas verso ek la Biblio, e pose parafrazas olu; VI-248.
parafulmino a protection against lightning; a lightning conductor.
paragrafo paragraph.
paragrelo a protection against hail.
paralaxo (astron.) parallax.
paralela, paralelo parallel (lines); paraleleso parallelism; paralela cirklo (geog.) circle of latitude.
paralelepipedo* (geom.) parallelopiped.
paralelogramo (geom.) parallelogram.

paralizar (tr., lit. and fig.) to paralyse, palsy; render powerless, destroy energy; paralizesar to be paralysed, have a paralytic stroke; paralizaceso paralytic stroke; paralizika, paraliziko paralytic (person). Ex.: Pavoro paralizis omna lua fakultati.
paralogismo* paralogism. V. exp.: Paralogismo esas rezonado nekoncie falsa o kande la premisi ne justifikas la dedukturo. Sofismo esas volata paralogismo o mis-rezonado.
paralumo a shade from light (as a shade for a lamp, a window blind, etc.).
paramento cloth cuff, turned-up end of the sleeve of a coat or gown; (cf. mansheto, ponyeto). Def.: Parto (ek drapo o simila stofo) di la maniko di vesto, qua esas trusita; VI-245.
parametro* (geom.) parametre (paremeter).
paranimfo (antiq.) paranymph.
parapeto parapet (-wall); (fort.) breast-work.
paraplasmo* (biol.) paraplasm, paramitome.
parapluvo anything which protects from rain; an umbrella.
parasuno any shade from the sun: a parasol.
paravento wind-screen.
parazita, parazitala, parazitatra (lit. and. fig.) parasitic(al); parazito of men, animals, plants, a parasite; parazitaro vermin; parazitesar to be a parasite; paraziteso parasitism.
Parco (myth.) Parca, one of the three Fates.
pardonar (tr.) to forgive, condone, overlook, pardon (ulu, ulo); (cf. indulgar). V. exp.: vid. exkuzar.
parear (tr.) to parry, ward off (a blow); (cf. shirmar).
parebriigar to make (ulu) dead-drunk.
parenkimo (anat., bot.) parenchyma.

parenta of the same family, related, akin; parento, parentulo, parentino a relative; (cf. patro); parentaro kinsfolk; parenteso relationship; parentigar to connect by marriage; bone parentigar la pueri to marry the children into good families; parenteskar kun nobelaro to become connected by marriage with the nobility.
parentezo (sign and phrase) parenthesis; parenteze in p.; by the way of (cf. incidente).
parfacar (tr.) to do (ulo) thoroughly, complete, carry through to the end.
parfendar (tr.) to split, cleave (ulo) through, asunder.
parfumo (substance and odor) pefume, fragrance, agreeable odo(u)r (cf. odorizar); parfumizar to perfume; parfumoza fragrant (naturally); parfumizita perfumed (artificially); parfumaquo scented water.
parhelio (astron.) parhelion.

pariar (tr.) to bet, lay a wager, stake (ulo, pri ulo); pariar por ulu to bet on someone; (fig.) to back (the success) of someone; pariar kontre ulu to bet with (against) someone; pario bet, wager; pariajo the stake; pariado mutuala «pari mutual». Ex.: Me parias 100 fr. kontre 50 fr. Pariar ke kavalo vinkos.
«paria» pariah, outcast.

parieto wall (serving as partition, as in a room); inner surface (of a vase, tube. etc.); (anat.) coat, wall (as of stomach); parieti walls, coatings; (anat., bot., zool.) paries, parietes; parietala relating to a wall; parietal; parietala osto, parietalo parietal bone; parietizar to put a wall in; chamber off (ulo); parietizita walled, chambered.
parietario (bot.) wall-pellitory, parietary (genus: Parietaria).
parirar (intr.) to go through (to end or destination).
parko park.

parkurar (intr.) to run through (to end or determined place); (fig.) to peruse (a book) quickly, to read cursorily; paro the running over, passage; parajo line taken, road, course (of a river), trip (of auto, etc.); (surg.) course, direction (of a wound).
parlamento parliament; parlamentano member of p.; parlamenteyo house of p.
parlementar* (intr., milit.) to parley: confer with an enemy; parlementanto, parlementero negotiator (of terms), bearer of a flag or truce.
parodiar (tr.) to parody, burlesque, travesty (ulo, ulu).

paroko parish priest, rector (cf. pastoro); parokala priestly; parokeso rectorship, living; parokeyo rectory, parsonage; parokio parish; parokiala parish, parochial (church, school, etc.)parokiano parishioner.

parolar (intr.) to speak, talk (pri) (cf. konversar, diskursar); paroligar to cause someone to talk; parola verbal, oral; parolo speaking, word; parolado speech, talk; parole by word of mouth, verbally; paroloza, parolema talkative, vebose, loquacious; parol(ach)adar to be verbose; paroltalento gift of speech; parolmaniero elocution (cf. diciono);parolyuro right to speak; parolajileso, rapideso volubility, fluency; paroltubo speaking trumpet (cf. vocokonduktilo); parolar la Franca (or,parolar France) to speak French; parolar segun la raciono to talk sense, reason; amikala paroli friendly words. V. exp.: vid. dicar.
paromo ferry (-boat); paromisto ferryman.
paronimo, paronima (gram.) paronym(ous). Def.: Vorti di simila formo od etimologio, ma di diferenta signifiki quale: abstraktar, distraktar.
paronomazio (rhet.) resemblance between words of different languages.
parotida, parotido (anat.) parotid (gland).
parotidito (med.) parotitis (cf. oreliono). Def.: Inflameso neinfektala di la parotido; M. XI-67.
paroxismo (med. and fig.) paroxysm, fit.
parqueto parquetry: inlaid flooring; parquetizar to parquet (a floor).

parto part, share, portion; part (in games, music, etc.); partigar to divide into different shares, portions; partoprenar (tr.) to take a share (in), participate (in); partigebla divisible into parts or shares; partoprenanto sharer, partaker, participant; partala partial: affecting a part only, not total;. Def.: Un porciono de de divebla toto. Ex.: Dividar ulo en quar parti. Partoprenar ula afero.
partenero partner (in a dance, in sports; N.B. not in business; cf asociito). Ant.: adverso.
partenogenezo* (zool., bot.) parthenogenesis.
patero (theat.) (Eng.) pit. (U.S.) parquet circle: part of ground floor under balcony.
partio party: collection of people for amusement, play, hunting, fishing, etc.
particiono (mus.) partition: score.
participo (gram.) participle.

partikulo (gram.) particle, a subordinate word never inflected, a preposition, conjunction, interjection; an affix; (phys.) particle: minute portion of matter; (R.C. rel.) particle, fragment of consecrated bread.

partikulara particular, peculiar, special; partikulareso, partikularajo peculiarity, particularity; partikulare particularly, especially, peculiarly; partikularigar to particularize, specify (cf. detalizar); partikularismo (rel., polit.) particularism. Ex.: Planto partikulara ad klimato. Partikulara amiko. Partikularajo (od, singularajo) di parolado esas idiotismo. Partikularigar la mikra detali. Il laboris partikulare (od, specale) bone. V. exp.: Partikulara esas la kontreajo di generala od universala; aparta signifikas quaze separita, izolita, sola; VII-154; kp. VII-476.

partiso party, a number of persons united against others of contrary opinion; (in a law-suit) litigant, party; partiseto faction; partisano party member; partisan; partisaneso; emeso partisanship; partisala, ema, partisana party, partisan.
partitiva, partitivo (gram.) partitive.
partizano partisan, a kind of halberd or pike.
partoprenar see parto.

parturar (tr.) to bear (a child), bring forth, beget, give birth to; to calve, lamb; (fig.) to produce, create; (cf. gravidigar); parturo childbirth, delivery, confinement, parturition (cf. akusho, genito); parturala puerperal; parturajo (of animals) a litter; parturintino woman in child-bed; parturbenediko churching (of a woman after a childbirth).
paruo (orni.) tomtit, titmouse, (genus: Parus).
parvenar (intr.) to arrive (at destination), to attain (one’s aim, fortune, success in life); parveninto, parvenintacho (fig.) successful person; parvenu, upstart.

pasar (tr., intr.) to pass (tra, super ulo); to pass (one’s life, time, etc.); to pass away; pas(ad)o passing, passage (on land: cf pasajar); pasanta, pasema passing, transitory; pasanto, pasero passer-by, passenger (on land); pasinta past, gone; pasinto one who has passed; (fig.) dead, vanished person; pasajo anything which is passed, gone; paseyo pass; passage (place); pasigar to cause to pass; to cause or allow (a boat, a vehicle) to pass (cf. preterpasar); paspermiso, pasletropass: permit for transit; pasvorto password. Ex.: Il pasis avan nia pordo. Pasar de Anglia a Francia. Tempo pasas. Pasar de un temo ad altra. Me preter-pasis lua domo. Pasigez la salo, me pregas!

pasabla passable, tolerable, middling, fair; pasable tolerably, rather, fairly, passably, pretty, indifferently. Def.: Indikanta grado o valoro meza, la minim alta, quan on povas aceptar o tolerar; III-205. Ex.: Ico esas pasabla vino. La teatrajo esis pasable bona. Ta muliero esas pasable bela. Esas pasable varma en ca chambro, ma ne sat varma por mea olda patro.

pasajar (intr.) to take passage (on a ship), be a passenger (on ship); to go by sea; pasajo passage, crossing; pasajanto, pasajeropassenger (on sea; cf. pasanto). Ex.: Me pasajis de Calais ad Dover. Me havis bela veturo dum la pasajo.
pasamano handrailing.
pasero (orni.) sparrow (Passer).
«pasha» (Turkish title) pasha.
pasifloro (bot.) passion-flower (genus: Passiflora).

pasiono passion: violent emotion; great love or fondness; vehement desire; pasionoza passionate, impassioned; pasionizar, pasioneskar (tr., intr.) to impassion. Ex.: Amoro ed odio esas la maxim forta pasioni. Il pasionoze amoris el. La muziko pasionizis me. Me pasioneskis pri muziko (E. I became passionately fond of music).
pasiva passive; pasivo (gram.) passive (voice); (com.) debt (owed) liability; pasiveso passiveness. Ant.:aktiva.
pasko (festo) Easter, the Passover; ala paschal; ala ovo an Easter egg; komuniar ye pasko to receive the sacrament at Easter.
pasmento, pasmenti passement(erie): trimmings of lace, gimp, braid of gold, silver, worsted, etc. for clothes an furniture.
paspelo edging, welt. Def.: Streta bendo de stofo (generale de diversa kolori), per qua on bordizas ula parti di vesto (kolumo, manchi; specale militistala); VI-142.
pasporto passport (cf. paspermiso).
pasto paste: any soft composition; (cook.) dough; (tech.) pâte; pastatra pasty, doughy.
pastelo pastel; (colo(u)red) crayon; pastelpiktar to paint in pastel.
pasterno pastern (of a horse).
pasteto pâte: pie, pasty (made of meat or fish); karno pasteto meat pie.
pasteurisar* (tr.) to pasteurize.
pastilo pastil: aromatic lozenge for breath; a preparation to scent the air.
pastinako (bot.) parsnip (Pastinaca sativa).
pasturar (tr., intr.) to pasture (animals), graze, browse, feed (off grass while moving); pastureyo (place) pasture; pasturajo (the food) pasturage; pasturyuro the right to pasture.
patar* (tr., intr.) to stalemate (at chess).
patato batata, sweet potato (Ipomoea Batatas).
patelo (anat.) patella, kneecap.
pateno (R.C. rel.) paten.
patento patent (of an invention); patentizar to patent (ulo).
«pater (noster)» pater(noster), Lord’s prayer.
patero curtain-peg, -hook.
patetika pathetic, touching; patetikeso pathos, patheticness (cf. patoso).
patibulo gallows (in the form: TT ; cf. jibeto).
patino patina, green film formed on metals.
patogena pathogenic.
patogenezo* pathogenesis.
patologio* pathology; patologiisto pathologist.
patoso pathos; patosacho bathos, bombast, fustian, rant (cf. patetikeso).

patro a parent (father or mother); patrulo father; patrino mother (cf. matro); patreto little father, papa; ge patriparents (both sexes);patrala, patrulatra paternal, fatherly; patrinala; patrinatra motherly, maternal; patruleso paternity; patrocido parricide.
patrio fatherland, (cf. naskolando).
patriarko (lit.and fig.) patriarch; patriarkeso patriarchate.
patrica, patrico patrician.
patrimonio patrimony, inheritance.
patrioto patriot; patriota, patriotala patriotic; patrioteso (quality) patriotism; patriotismo (doctrine taught) patriotism. V. exp.: vid. civismo.
patristiko (theol.) patristics. V. exp.: Cienco pri la doktrino dil ekleziala patri.
patroliar (intr.) to go on patrol, go the rounds; patroliigar to patrol (ulu).
patrologio (theol.) patrology. V. exp.: Cienco pri la verki e la vivo dil akleziala patri.

patrono (antiq.) patron; (modern) patron, supporter, protector; employer; (eccl.) advowee; patron saint; patroneso patronage: authority or position of a patron; patronesar (tr., intr.) to be a patron (ulu, ulo), to patronize: support (ulu).
pauperismo pauperism.
pauzar (intr.) to pause: stop temporarily; (mus.) to make a rest. Ex.: Pauzar dum lektado, dum kantado. Pauzar plurfoye en voyo.
pavo paving stone, cobble-stone; -aro, pavizuro pavement; pavizar to pave.
pavano pavan. Def.: Anciena danso (hispana origine); IV-395.
paviliono pavilion: a large peaked tent; a building with a tent-like roof; (cf. tendo).
pavono (orni.) peacock (genus: Pavo); pavonumar (intr.) to strut (like a peacock), pose.

pavorar (intr.) to be afraid, be in fear, be in a funk; pavorigar to frighten (ulu); pavoreskar to take fright, begin to be scared; pavoro fear, fright; (cf. alarmo, paniko); pavoroza fearful; pavorem(ul)o a timid person; sen pavora intrepid, fearless. V. exp.: Timo esas sentimento intelektala, preske tote intelektala, ofte («me timas ne finor mea laboro»). Pavoro esas instantala sentimento, nereflektata e nerepresebla, ofte tote senmotiva ed absurda (pavor pri araneo, muso, e.c.) «La generalo ne pavoris, ma il timas, ke lua soldati pavoros». Teroro esas tre granda pavoro, qua igas tremar e qua supresas omna reflekto. Hororo esas sentimento di repulseso plu kam pavoro; etimologie ol signifikas heriso (di la hari e pili). Angoro esas propre fiziologial sento di konstrikto di la fauco e di quaza sufoko, pro desquieteso o pasionoza expekto; II-79, 648; IV-236.

pazar (intr.) to take steps, to stride, step (out), stalk (along); pazetar to trip along, take short steps; pazo step, pace, gait; pazo granda stride; pazope step by step; pazi silencoza soft or stealthy steps; pazo rapida (milit.) quick time, quick march; trans, superpazar to stride across, step over, straddle; pazo kontilo pedometer (cf. hodometro).
pazigrafio* pasigraphy. Def.: Irga sistemo di universala skribado, qua uzas signi, partikulare matematikala simboli, por reprezentar idei, ne vorti.
peano pean, pæan. Def.: Himno o kanto por honorizar ulu, ulo; militala kanto; vinkala kanto.

peco piece; lump (of sugar, of beef, etc.); (cf. fragmento, parto, porciono); peceto morsel, small bit; pec(et)igar to break, cut, tear (ulo) into pieces; to crumble; peceskar to fall to pieces; peceteskar to crumble; pecope piece by piece, bit by bit, piecemeal; peci omnaspeca, peci diversa odds and ends; peco prenebla (in checkers, etc.) a piece which can be taken; unpece in one piece; monetpeco a piece of money; peci de ruptita vazopieces of a broken vase. V. exp.: Peco signifikas: «parto di kontinua toto, qua konstitucas ipse unajo o toto; qua havas ula propra uneso» (on pensez pri la peci di mashino). Do on povas bone parolar pri peco de drapo, pri monetpeco; e konseque pri parto di peco. Ne esas tre utila parolar pri panpeco, fromajopeco suficas dicar pano, fromajo; IV-352.
«peccavi» peccavi (L. I have sinned).
pecho pitch; pechoza pitchy; pechatra sticky; pechizar to pitch, cover with pitch.

pedo (anat. and fig.) foot; (of animals) paw; (of verse) foot; pedala pedal, relating to the foot; pedalo (tech.) pedal; treadle; foot-board; pedalagar (intr.) to pedal, work the pedal (of a bicycle, organ, etc.); pedobalno foot-bath; pedbutar to stumble; pedfrapar (tr.) to kick (cf. kikar); pedfingro a toe; pedirar (intr.) to go on foot; pedirante on foot; pedirala, iranto, pedero pedestrian; pedkolo instep; pedokuracado chiropody; pedsoldato foot-soldier, infantryman; pedvestizar to put boots, shoes, stockings on (ulu); pedotaburetofoot-stool; marchar pe quar pedi to go on all fours; sen pedaapodal, footless.
pedagogopedagogue.
pedagogio pedagogy.
pedanto pedant; pedantino (fig.) blue-stocking.
pederasto pederast.
pedikulo (bot., anat.) pedicel, stipe, stem, stalk.
pedikuloso* pediculosis: a lousy state.
pedunklo (bot., zool., anat.) peduncle.
pego (orni.) woodpecker (Picus).
pegazo (myth., astron.) Pegasus.
peizajo (natural, artistic) landscape, scenery; peizajisto landscape painter.
pejorativa, pejorativo pejorative, depreciative (word).

pekar (intr.) to sin; (fig.) to transgress, offend; peko sin (original, mortal, venial);peketo slight offense, peccadillo; pekoza sinful, wicked; pekokonfeso confession of sin; pekanta, pekema, pekiva sinning peccable; pekokapr(ul)o scapegoat. Ex.: Pekar kontre la imperi di Deo. (fig.) Pekar kontre la komuna raciono.
pekario (zool.) peccary (Dicotyles torquartus).
pekino* (fabric) pekin.
pektar (tr.) to comb (the hair); to card (wool, etc.); pektilo a comb; pektisto comber, carder (in a factory); pektohari, pektrezidui combings.
pektino* (chem.) pectin.
pektorochest, breast (cf. mamo, pulmono, sino); pektorala pectoral; pektoralo (anat.) pectoral muscle; pectoral, any breast object; pektorvesto (of women) bodice.
pektoso* (chem.) pectose.
pekunio (ready) money, cash; pekuniala pecuniary; pekunioquanto sum of money; (cf. moneto).
pelagika* pelagic.? DEFIS
pelagro (med.) pellagra.
pelargonio (bot.) pelargonium.
pelerino pelerine, a kind of cape, tippet worn by ladies.
pelikano (orni.) pelican (genus: Pelicanus).
pelikulo pellicle.
peliso (garment) pelisse.
pelmelo pell-mell, hurly-burly, hubbub, jumbled mass, medley, litter; pelmele helter-skelter.
pelorio* (biol.) peloria.
peloto ball (formed of thread, silk, etc. wound round); pelotigar to make (ulo) into a ball; to wind. Def.: Bulo ek filo volvita; III-205.
pelotono (milit.) platoon.
pelvo (anat.) pelvis.
pemikano* pemmican.

penar (intr.) to take the trouble (to do something or to do something difficult of execution), to take pains; (cf. esforcar); penigar to put (ulu) to trouble (to do something); peni pains (taken); pene with difficulty; penege, per granda peno with great trouble, with much difficulty; to ne valoras la peno that is nor worth the trouble; me penas facar ca laboro I take pains in doing this work.
penacho panache, a plume or bunch of feathers, as on a helmet.
penati (antiq.) penates, household gods.

pendar (tr., intr.) to hang (up or down), suspend, dangle; pendigar to cause (ulu, ulo) to be hanged or hung; pendajo, pendpeco something hung; pendant; pendanto, pendero one who hangs; a hangman; pendinda worthy of hanging. Ex.: La frukti pendas de la abori. Pendar animalo per la pedi. La judiciisto pendigas la trahizinti (E. the judge caused the traitors to be hung). Juvelo pendanta.
pendentivo (arch.) pendentive.
pendulo pendulum; pendulhorlojo pendulum clock.

penetrar (tr., intr.; lit. and fig.) to penetrate, pierce (cf. perforar, borar); penetrigar to cause (ulo) to penetrate (en ulo); penetranta, penetriva, penetrema penetrating, piercing (fig.) sagacious, acute, keen; penetremeso acuteness, shrewdness. Ex.: La kuglo penetris la korpo. (fig.) La trupi penetris la lando. La penso penetris lua mento. Penetranta okuli. Penetrema mento.
peninsulo peninsula.
peniso penis.
penitencar (intr.) to do penance; (cf. repentar); penitenco, penitenceso penance, penitence.

pensar (tr., intr.) to think; penso, pensado a thought, thinking, cogitation; pensema thoughtful, pensive; penseskar to have an idea; (cf. meditar, reflektar, rezonar, intelektar, imaginar, konceptar, memorar, sonjar, revar, kredar, judikar, opinionar). Def.: Formacar ideo pri ulu, ulo. Ex.: Me pensis (pri) ulo quo povas helpar vu. La homo qua pensas povas esar la mastro di qui ne pensas. Pensez ante ke vu facos to.

pensionar (tr.) to pension (soldiers, etc.)to pay a regular stipulated sum for board and lodging; pensiono regular payment, board and lodging, regular charge. Def.: Pagar reguloze ula sumo por manteno. V. exp.: Pensiono esas sumo quan ulu pagas o recevas reguloze por lua manteno. Ica senco kontenas ta di pensiono (1) di oficero od oficisto en retreto; ol kontenas anke ta di la pensiono (2) di skolano «interna», qua lojas e nutresas en edukerio, e ta di la pensiono (3) di gasto di hotelo, qua anke lojas e nutresas, o nur nutresas. Takaze ta qua recevas pensiono (1) esus pensionato, pensionario; qua pagas pension (2) o (3) esas pensionanto, pensionero; la loko ipsa esas pensioneyo, pensionerio; V-282.

pento (downward) slope, incline, gradient, pitch, declivity; penta, pente (downward) sloping, shelving. V. exp.: Rampo e pento esas esence sama, ma pento esas la inklinajo de supre ad infre, e rampo la sinso de infre ad supre; rampo acensas, pento decensas.
pentaedro* (geom.) pentagedron.
pentagono* (geom.) pentagon.
pentagramo (geom.) pentagram.
pentametro (verse) pentameter.
pentarko* pentarchos, one of five rulers; quinquivir.
pentatlo (antiq.) pentathlon.
pentekosto Pentecost, Whitsunday.
penvalorar (intr.) to be worth while.
peonio (bot.) peony (genus: Pæonia).
pepito (min.) nugget (especially of silver or gold).
pepsino (chem. pharm.) pepsin.
peptono (physiol. chem.) peptone.

per (prep.) by means of, through the help of, by, with (marks, instrument, means); (arith.) multiplied by (the sign); (cf. da); per ke through the fact that. Ex.: Pruvar per exempli. Trapikar per poniardo. Sendar letro per posto. La substantivi finas per «o» en la singularo. Lu sucesis vinkar, per ke lu uzis ruzo. Quar per du facas ok.

perceptar (tr.) to perceive: to receive impressions of external objects; to feel; discern; percept(ad)o perception; perceptiva perceptive (faculty, etc.); perceptebla perceptible; ne ebla imperceptible. Def.: Komprenar per la sensi. Ex.: Perceptar ula bruiso. Materiaji esas sole perceptebla.

perchar (intr.) to perch; to roost (sur); perchilo a roost; percheyo perching place; (fig.) upper gallery in a theater (theatre). V.: exp.: Perchar aplikesas, ne nur a hani, ma ad omnaspeca uceli, e mem metafore ad animali e homi; III-327.

perdar (tr.) to lose (cf. egarar); perdesarto be lost, be a loser; perdo loss; perdajo what is lost; perde vendar to sell at a loss. Def.: Cesar havar to quon on posedis o proprietis. Ex.: Perdar sua burso, fundo, voyo, raciono, parento. Ant.: ganar.
perdriko (orni.) partridge; perdrikyuno a young partridge.
perena perennial. Def.: Qua duras plura yari; V-89.

perfekta perfect (cf. bonega, ecelanta); perfekteso perfection; perfekte perfectly (cf. komplete, tote); perfektigar to perfect, bring to perfection; perfektigebla perfectible. Def.: Qua havas omna sua qualesi sen inter-mixuro di defekti. Ex.: Perfekta baleso, vino, homo, boneso.
perfekto (gram.) perfect.
perfida, perfid(ulo) perfidious, felonious, false-hearted, treacherous (person); perfidajo act of perfidy. Ant.: loyala.
perforar (tr.) to perforate, pierce through; (cf. borar, penetrar). Def.: Truifar sen rotaco; III-165. Ex.: Kuglo perforas korpo, muro.
pergamena, pergameno parchment; pergamenatra parchmentlike, pergamentaceous.
perianto (bot.) perianth.
periferio periphery, circumference.
perifrazar (tr.) to periphrase; express in a roundabout way, by circumlocution. V. exp.: vid.: parafrazo. Exp.: «La rejo dil uceli» esas perifrazo por l’aglo.
perigeo (astron.) perigree. Ant.: apogeo.
perihelio* (astron.) perihelion.
perikardio (anat.) pericardium.
perikarpo (bot.) pericarp, seed-vessel.
perimetro perimeter.
perineo (anat.) perineum.
periosto (anat.) periosteum.
periostito* (med.) periostitis.
peripatetika, peripatetik(ul)o peripatetic, Aristotelian. (N.B. not fig.).
peripecio peripetia, sudden turn of fortune, vicissitude; (theat.) denouement.
periplo (ancient geog.) periplus (a sailing round). Def.: Historiala nomo di ula specala cirkumnavigi, e naraco di li; V-89.
perisar (intr.) to perish: die; be destroyed, ruined; perisiva, perisema perishable. Ex.: Mili di soldati perisis en ta batalio. (fig.) Lua nomo ne povos perisar. Flori perisas.
periskopo* periscope.
peristalta* (physiol.) peristaltic.
peristilo (arch.) peristyle.
peritoneo (anat.) peritoneum. ?EFIS
peritonito (med.) peritonitis.
perjurar (intr.) to perjure: violate one’s oath, (fig.) to break one’s word. Def.: Violacar promiso facita per juro; V-430.
perko (ich.) perch (genus: Perca).
perkalo (fabric) percale.
perkalino (fabric) percaline.

perkutar (tr., also med.) to percuss; perkuto percussion: shock of one body against another; perkutilo, instrumento instrument of percussion; (of guns) hammer, bolt (which sets off the cartridge). Def.: Frapar forte. Ex.: La perkutilo perkutas la amorcilo. La cimbalisto perkutas la cimbali. La mediko exploras per perkutado.
perlo pearl; artificala, falsa perlo imitation pearl; vera perlo a real pearl; prizentar perli a porki (fig.) to cast pearls before swine; perlifanta pearl-bearing.
perlomatra, perlomatro mother-of-pearl.
permanar (intr.) to be permanent; permano, permananteso permanence; permananta armeo standing army.
permear (tr.) to permeate, pervade; permeebligar to render (ulo) permeable. Ex.: L’aquo permeas sulo. L’odoro permeas l’aero.

permisar (tr.) to permit, allow, give leave to, authorize, give license to; (N.B. This verb is transitive in relation to the thing, but intransitive relative to the person). -o permission, consent; permisoatesto written authorization, a permit (cf. konjedo, licenco); permiso parola verbal permission; permisario one granted a permit; permisez a me allow me! may I be permitted! Def.: Donar libereso o yuro facar, dicar (ulo ad ulu). Ex.: Ka vu permisas ke me apertas la fenestro? Esas permisata a vu promenar en ca gardeno.

permutar (tr.) to transpose, interchange, permute; permutite vice versa. V. exp.: Permutar esas chanjar l’ordino di plura kozi, qui duras formacar kolekturo. Me chanjas mea vesti kande me desmetas uli e metas altri. Ma me permutas li, kande (sen metar li) me chanjas lia ordino en mea vesteyo. Kande on mixas ludkarti qui restas sempre sama, on facas nur permuti; on chanjas li kande on prenas altra paketo de karti vice l’unesma; VII-204.
perono perron, an out-of-door flight of steps; outside stair-case; front-door steps.
peroneo* (anat.) perone, fibula, small bone of the leg. ? eFS
peronosporo peronospora: a genus of fungi.
peroraciono (rhet.) peroration. Ant.: exordio. Def.: Lasta parto, konkluzo di diskurso.
perpendikla: perpendicular.

perpetua perpetual, forever; (fig.) for life; perpetue everlastingly; perpetueso perpetuity; perpetuigar to perpetuate. Def.: Kontinua, qua ne cesas. Ex.: Perpetua fairo brulis sur la altaro di Vesta. Perpetua movado. Perpetua exilo.

perplexa perplexed, puzzled; perplexeso perplexity: embarrassment of mind; irresolution. Ex.: Perplexa pro desfacilaji neprevidita. Situeso perplexigiva. V. exp.: Perplexa expresas nociono komplexa, quaze meza inter embarasata e nequieta (kun nuanco di hezito); V-89.

perquizita (tr.) to make (legal) search, inquiry (pri ulu, ulo); perquizito perquisition; search; perquizito mandato search-warrant. Def.: (Perquizito) Legala, judiciista serchado; figurale, tre severa ed exakta serchado, generale malvolanta o suspektema; III-392. Ex.: Perquizitar apartamento di persono suspektinda.

persekutar (tr.) to persecute: harass unjustly; (fig.) to importune, annoy. V. exp.: Persequar esas: proxime sequar persiste, por atingar ulu od obtenar ulo. Ex.: Persequar furtisto. Persequar cervo en chaso. Persequar la glorio, la plezuro, la suceso. Persequar ulu avan tribunalo. Persekutar esas: kruele traktar ulu persiste. Ex.: La mali persekutas la boni, pro ke li odias lo bona. La Kristani persekutesis dum la unesma yarcenti di l’eklezio; V-430.
persequar (tr.) to pursue (with a view to overtake); (jur.) to prosecute; persequesar (da) to be pursued, prosecuted (by); persequeskar to start pursuit; to indict, sue. V. exp.: vid. persekutar.

perseverar (intr.) to persevere, pursue steadfastly: continue on a given course, esp. in the face of discouragement, obstacles; (cf. persistar). Ex.: Perseverar en ula entraprezo. Il esas persever-anta, -ema homo.
persieno persienne, (outside) Venetian shutter; the ordinary outside window-blinds with movable slats; (cf. III-290; jelozio).
persiko (fruit) a peach; persikiero peach tree (Amygdalus persica); persikkerno peach-stone; persikliquoro a persicot (a cordial).
persikario (bot.) persicaria, lady’s thumb (Polygonum persicaria).

persistar (intr.) to persist: hold firm, continue steadfast (en, pri) (cf. perseverar). Ex.: La testo persistas negar. Il persistas en sua opiniono. Persistanta morbo. Persistema homo. V. exp.: vid. insistar.

persono person (man, woman, child); (theol., gram.) person; (cf. individuo); personala personal; personaro personnel; personeso personality, individuality: quality of being a person; personaleso quality of being personal (to someone); personalajo personal peculiarity; personal remark; persone, personale in person, personally, in a personal manner; personego personage: a great person or person of distinction; personigar to personify (ulo); personospegulo cheval-glass: a full-length dressing-glass.
perspektiva, perspektivo perspective; perspektive in perspective, in the distance. Ex.: Lineala perpektivo. Desegnuro perspektiva.
perturbar (tr., astron., social) to perturb, trouble, unsettle, throw into disorder; perturbanta, perturbiva perturbing, disturbing. Ex.: Perturbo di la mento. Perturbi sociala, financala.
perucho (orni.) parrakeet, parroquet.
peruko wig, periwig, peruke; perukisto wig-maker. Def.: Kuafuro de falsa hararo.
perversa perverse, obstinate in the wrong, wayward, depraved; perversigar to pervert. Def.: Qua havas nenormala o kontreetika tendenci (o gusto); III-205.
pervinko (bot.) periwinkle (genus: Vinca).
pesario (surg.) pessary.
pesimismo pessimism; pesimisto, pesima pessimist(ic).
